revision.text:
{{Year box}} '''1924 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport.
==[[American football]]== * [[History of National Football League Championship|NFL Championship]] – [[Cleveland Bulldogs]] *[[Anthracite League|Anthracite League champions]] – [[Pottsville Maroons]]
==[[Association football]]== '''England''' * [[The Football League]] – [[Huddersfield Town]] 57 points, [[Cardiff City]] 57, [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] 53, [[Bolton Wanderers]] 50, [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]] 50, [[Aston Villa]] 49 * [[1924 FA Cup Final|FA Cup final]] – [[Newcastle United]] 2–0 [[Aston Villa]] at [[Wembley Stadium (1924)|Empire Stadium, Wembley, London]] '''Germany''' * [[List of German football champions|National Championship]] – [[1. FC Nürnberg]] 2–0 [[Hamburger SV]] at Berlin '''Greece''' * [[AEK Athens]] officially founded on April 13.{{citation needed|date=December 2016}} '''Monaco''' * [[AS Monaco FC|AS Monaco]] officially founded on August 23.{{citation needed|date=December 2016}}
==[[Track and field athletics|Athletics]]== '''Men's 1500 metres''' * [[Paavo Nurmi]] (Finland) breaks the world record by running a time of 3:52.6 at [[Helsinki]].
'''England''' * [[1924 Women's Olympiad]], [[Stamford Bridge (stadium)|Stamford Bridge]], London
==[[Australian rules football]]== '''VFL Premiership''' * [[Essendon Football Club|Essendon]] wins the 28th [[Australian Football League|VFL]] Premiership: under the finals system used, no Grand Final is played. '''Brownlow Medal''' * The inaugural [[Brownlow Medal]] is awarded to [[Edward Greeves]] of [[Geelong Football Club|Geelong]].
==[[Bandy]]== '''Sweden''' * [[Swedish bandy champions|Championship final]] – [[Västerås SK Bandy|Västerås SK]] 4–1 [[IF Linnéa]]
==[[Baseball]]== '''World Series''' * 4–10 October — [[Washington Senators (1901–60)|Washington Senators]] (AL) defeats [[New York Giants (NL)|New York Giants]] (NL) to win the [[1924 World Series]] by 4 games to 3 '''Negro League Baseball''' * [[Kansas City Monarchs]] ([[Negro National League (1920–1931)|NNL]]) defeats [[Hilldale Club|Hilldale]] ([[Eastern Colored League|ECL]]) 5 games to 4 with 1 tie in the first official [[1924 Colored World Series|Negro League World Series]]. * Pitcher [[Nip Winters]] wins a record 27 games for [[Hilldale Club|Hilldale]] in the ECL regular season.
==[[Biathlon]]== '''1924 Winter Olympics''' * [[Military patrol]], the forerunner of [[biathlon]] which combines [[cross-country skiing]] and [[shooting sports|rifle shooting]], is staged as a demonstration event at the inaugural [[Winter Olympics]] in [[Chamonix]]. The winning team is Switzerland.
==[[Bobsleigh]]== '''1924 Winter Olympics''' * Bobsleigh debuts oaiusfhkuhoidsfuhoiuhin [[Chamonix]] at the inaugural [[Winter Olympics]]. The sole event is the 4-man bob which is won by Switzerland I (gold) ahead of Great Britain II (silver) and Belgium I (bronze).
==[[Boxing]]== '''Events''' * 10 August — the [[World Featherweight Champion]]ship title becomes vacant as [[Johnny Dundee]] relinquishes it to fight as a lightweight '''Lineal world champions'''<ref>[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/pastchp.htm Cyber Boxing Zone]</ref> * [[World Heavyweight Champion]]ship – [[Jack Dempsey]] * [[World Light Heavyweight Champion]]ship – [[Mike McTigue]] * [[World Middleweight Champion]]ship – [[Harry Greb]] * [[World Welterweight Champion]]ship – [[Mickey Walker (boxer)|Mickey Walker]] * [[World Lightweight Champion]]ship – [[Benny Leonard]] * [[World Featherweight Champion]]ship – [[Johnny Dundee]] → vacant * [[World Bantamweight Champion]]ship – [[Joe Lynch (boxer)|Joe Lynch]] → [[Abe Goldstein]] → Eddie "Cannonball" Martin * [[World Flyweight Champion]]ship – [[Francisco Guilledo|Pancho Villa]]
==[[Canadian football]]== '''Grey Cup''' * [[12th Grey Cup]] in the [[Canadian Football League]] – Queen's University 11–2 [[Toronto Balmy Beach Beachers|Toronto Balmy Beach]]
==[[Cricket]]== '''Events''' * [[England national cricket team|England]] defeats [[South Africa national cricket team|South Africa]] 3–0 with two matches drawn. There is a sensational start to the series when the South Africans are bowled out for only 30, in just 12.3 overs, in their first innings of the First Test at [[Edgbaston Cricket Ground|Edgbaston]], England having made over 400. '''England''' * [[County Championship]] – [[Yorkshire County Cricket Club|Yorkshire]] * [[Minor Counties Championship]] – [[Berkshire County Cricket Club|Berkshire]] * Most runs – [[Frank Woolley]] 2344 @ 49.87 (HS 202) * Most wickets – [[Maurice Tate]] 205 @ 13.74 (BB 8–18) * [[Wisden Cricketers of the Year]] – [[Bob Catterall]], [[Jack MacBryan]], [[Herbie Taylor]], [[Dick Tyldesley]], [[Dodger Whysall]] '''Australia''' * [[Sheffield Shield]] – [[Victoria cricket team|Victoria]] * Most runs – [[Bill Ponsford]] 777 @ 111.00 (HS 248) * Most wickets – [[Albert Hartkopf]] and [[Norman Williams (Australian cricketer)|Norman Williams]] 26 apiece '''India''' * [[Bombay Quadrangular]] – [[Hindus cricket team|Hindus]] '''New Zealand''' * [[Plunket Shield]] – [[Wellington cricket team|Wellington]] '''South Africa''' * [[SuperSport Series|Currie Cup]] – [[Transvaal cricket team|Transvaal]] '''West Indies''' * [[Inter-Colonial Tournament]] – [[Barbados cricket team|Barbados]]
==[[Curling]]== '''1924 Winter Olympics''' * Curling is played at the inaugural [[1924 Winter Olympics|Winter Olympics]]. It is a demonstration sport at the time but is retrospectively granted official status. The gold medal is won by the Great Britain and Ireland team.
==[[Cycling]]== '''Tour de France''' * [[Ottavio Bottecchia]] (Italy) wins the 18th [[1924 Tour de France|Tour de France]]
==[[Field hockey]]== '''Events''' * 7 January — the [[International Hockey Federation]] (FIH) is founded in Paris by seven member countries: Austria, Belgium, Czechoslovakia, France, Hungary, Spain and Switzerland.
==[[Figure skating]]== '''Events''' * Figure skating is included in the inaugural [[1924 Winter Olympics|Winter Olympics]], having already featured in the [[1908 Summer Olympics|1908]] and [[1920 Summer Olympics]]. The Olympic gold medallists and the world championship winners are the same in all three events. '''1924 Winter Olympics''' * Men's individual – [[Gillis Grafström]] (Sweden) * Women's individual – [[Herma Szabo]] (Austria) * Pairs – Helene Engelmann and Alfred Berger (Austria) '''World Figure Skating Championships''' * [[World Figure Skating Championships|World Men's Champion]] – [[Gillis Grafström]] (Sweden) * [[World Figure Skating Championships|World Women's Champion]] – [[Herma Szabo]] (Austria) * [[World Figure Skating Championships|World Pairs Champions]] – Helene Engelmann and Alfred Berger (Austria)
==[[Golf]]== '''Major tournaments''' * [[1924 Open Championship|British Open]] – [[Walter Hagen]] * [[1924 U.S. Open (golf)|US Open]] – [[Cyril Walker]] * [[1924 PGA Championship|USPGA Championship]] – [[Walter Hagen]] '''Other tournaments''' * [[The Amateur Championship|British Amateur]] – [[Ernest Holderness]] * [[United States Amateur Championship (men's golf)|US Amateur]] – [[Bobby Jones (golfer)|Bobby Jones]]
==[[Horse racing]]== '''Events''' * The inaugural running of the [[Cheltenham Gold Cup]] is won by Red Splash '''England''' * [[Cheltenham Gold Cup]] – [[Red Splash]] * [[1924 Grand National|Grand National]] – Master Robert * [[1,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Plack (horse)|Plack]] * [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Diophon]] * [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – [[Sansovino (horse)|Sansovino]] * [[Epsom Oaks|The Oaks]] – [[Straitlace]] * [[St. Leger Stakes]] – [[Salmon-Trout]] '''Australia''' * [[Melbourne Cup]] – Backwood '''Canada''' * [[Queen's Plate]] – Maternal Pride '''France''' * [[Prix de l'Arc de Triomphe]] – Massine '''Ireland''' * [[Irish Grand National]] – Kilbarry * [[Irish Derby Stakes]] – Haine ''dead heated with'' Zodiac '''USA''' * [[1924 Kentucky Derby|Kentucky Derby]] – Black Gold * [[Preakness Stakes]] – Nellie Morse * [[Belmont Stakes]] – Mad Play
==[[Ice hockey]]== '''Events''' * Ice hockey is included in the inaugural [[1924 Winter Olympics|Winter Olympics]], having already featured in the [[1920 Summer Olympics]]. Canada successfully defends the Olympic title. '''1924 Winter Olympics''' * Gold Medal – Canada * Silver Medal – USA * Bronze Medal – Great Britain '''Stanley Cup''' * 22–25 March — [[Montreal Canadiens]] defeats [[Calgary Tigers]] by 2 games to 0 in the [[1924 Stanley Cup Finals]] '''Events''' * [[Sault Ste. Marie Greyhounds]] defeats the [[Winnipeg Selkirks]] 6–3 to win the [[Allan Cup]] * 1 December — the expansion [[Boston Bruins]] and [[Montreal Maroons]] of the NHL play their inaugural game against each other at Boston. Boston wins this game 2–1 but then lose eleven in a row.
==[[Motorsport]]== {{main|1924 in motorsport|List of 1924 motorsport champions}}
==[[Nordic skiing]]== '''Events''' * Nordic skiing stages its first international competitions at the inaugural Winter Olympics in [[Chamonix]]. Four events are held (for men only): [[cross-country skiing]] over 18 km and 50 km; [[ski jumping]] on the large hill; and [[Nordic combined]] as an individual event. '''1924 Winter Olympics''' * [[Cross-country skiing]] (18 km) – gold medal: [[Thorleif Haug]] (Norway) * Cross-country skiing (50 km) – gold medal: [[Thorleif Haug]] (Norway) * [[Ski jumping]] – gold medal: [[Jacob Tullin Thams]] (Norway) * [[Nordic combined]] – gold medal: [[Thorleif Haug]] (Norway)
==[[Olympic Games]]== '''1924 Winter Olympics''' * The [[1924 Winter Olympics]], the inaugural [[Winter Olympics]], takes place in [[Chamonix]], France. It is originally called ''Semaine des Sports d'Hiver'', or "International Winter Sports Week". * Norway wins the most medals (18) and the most gold medals (5) '''1924 Summer Olympics''' * The [[1924 Summer Olympics]] takes place in Paris * United States wins the most medals (99) and the most gold medals (45)
==[[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]]== '''The Boat Race''' * 5 April — [[Cambridge University Boat Club|Cambridge]] wins the 76th [[The Boat Race|Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race]]
==[[Rugby league]]== '''England''' * [[Rugby Football League Championship|Championship]] – [[Batley Bulldogs|Batley]] * [[Challenge Cup|Challenge Cup final]] – [[Wigan Warriors|Wigan]] 21–4 [[Oldham R.L.F.C.|Oldham]] at [[Athletic Grounds, Rochdale]] * [[Rugby league county leagues|Lancashire League Championship]] – [[Wigan Warriors|Wigan]] * [[Rugby league county leagues|Yorkshire League Championship]] – [[Batley Bulldogs|Batley]] * [[RFL Lancashire Cup|Lancashire]] [[Rugby league county cups|County Cup]] – [[St Helens Recreation RLFC|St Helens Recs]] 17–0 [[Swinton Lions|Swinton]] * [[RFL Yorkshire Cup|Yorkshire]] [[Rugby league county cups|County Cup]] – [[Hull F.C.]] 10–4 [[Huddersfield Giants|Huddersfield]] '''Australia''' * [[New South Wales Rugby League premiership|NSW Premiership]] – [[Balmain Tigers|Balmain]] 3–0 [[South Sydney Rabbitohs|South Sydney]] (grand final)
==[[Rugby union]]== '''Five Nations Championship''' * 37th [[1924 Five Nations Championship|Five Nations Championship]] series is won by [[England national rugby union team|England]] who complete the [[Grand Slam (rugby union)|Grand Slam]]
==[[Speed skating]]== '''Events''' * Speed skating debuts as an Olympic sport in [[Chamonix]] at the inaugural [[Winter Olympics]]. Five men only events are held. '''Speed Skating World Championships''' * [[World Allround Speed Skating Championships for Men|Men's All-round Champion]] – [[Roald Larsen]] (Norway) '''1924 Winter Olympics''' * 500m – gold medal: [[Charles Jewtraw]] (USA) * 1500m – gold medal: [[Clas Thunberg]] (Finland) * 5000m – gold medal: [[Clas Thunberg]] (Finland) * 10000m – gold medal: [[Julius Skutnabb]] (Finland) * All-round – gold medal: [[Clas Thunberg]] (Finland)
==[[Tennis]]== '''Australia''' * [[List of Australian Open Men's Singles champions|Australian Men's Singles Championship]] – [[James Anderson (tennis)|James Anderson]] (Australia) defeats [[Richard Schlesinger (tennis)|Richard Schlesinger]] (Australia) 6–3 6–4 3–6 5–7 6–3 * [[List of Australian Open Women's Singles champions|Australian Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Sylvia Lance Harper]] (Australia) defeats [[Esna Boyd Robertson]] (Australia) 6–3 3–6 8–6 '''England''' * [[The Championships Wimbledon|Wimbledon Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Jean Borotra]] (France) defeats [[René Lacoste]] (France) 6–1 3–6 6–1 3–6 6–4 * [[The Championships Wimbledon|Wimbledon Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Kitty McKane Godfree]] (Great Britain) defeats [[Helen Wills Moody]] (USA) 4–6 6–4 6–4 '''France''' * [[List of French Open Men's Singles champions and finalists|French Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Jean Borotra]] (France) defeats [[René Lacoste]] (France) 7–5 6–4 0–6 5–7 6–2 * [[List of French Open Women's Singles champions|French Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Emilienne Didi Vlasto]] (France) defeats [[Jeanne Vaussard]] (France) 6–2 6–3 '''USA''' * [[List of US Open Men's Singles champions|American Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Bill Tilden]] (USA) defeats [[Bill Johnston (tennis)|Bill Johnston]] (USA) 6–1 9–7 6–2 * [[List of US Open Women's Singles champions|American Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Helen Wills Moody]] (USA) defeats [[Molla Bjurstedt Mallory]] (Norway) 6–1 6–3 '''Davis Cup''' * [[1924 International Lawn Tennis Challenge]] – {{davis|USA|1912}} 5–0 {{davis|AUS}} at [[Germantown Cricket Club]] (grass) [[Philadelphia]], United States
==References== {{Reflist}}

[[Al-Sareeh SC]] | seating_capacity = 12,000 (after installation of seats) | dimensions = | scoreboard = }} '''Al-Hasan Stadium''' ({{Lang-ar|مَلعب الحَسن}}) is a [[multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Irbid]], [[Jordan]]. It is currently used mostly for [[football (soccer)|football]] matches. The stadium holds 12,000 people. {{Coord|32|32|15|N|35|51|37|E|type:landmark|display=title}} [[Category:Football venues in Jordan]] [[Category:Multi-purpose stadiums in Jordan]] [[Category:Sport in Irbid]] {{Jordan-sports-venue-stub}}

{{Infobox cricket ground | ground_name = Al Amerat Cricket Stadium | nickname = Amerat Turf | country = Sultanate of Oman | location = [[Muscat, Oman]]{{coord|23|29|17.1|N|58|29|38.3|E|region:OM-MA_type:landmark|display=title}} | establishment = 2012 | seating_capacity = n/a | owner = [[Oman Cricket Board]] | operator = [[Oman Cricket]] | tenants = [[Oman national cricket team]] | end1 = | end2 = | international = | firstodidate = | firstodiyear = | firstodihome = | firstodiaway = | lastodidate = | lastodiyear = | lastodihome = | lastodiaway = | firstt20idate = | firstt20iyear = | firstt20ihome = | firstt20iaway = | lastt20idate = | lastt20iyear = | lastt20ihome = | lastt20iaway = | date = 5 November | year = 2018 |publictransit = | source = [http://www.espncricinfo.com/ireland/content/ground/1095893.html Cricinfo Ministry Turf 1]
[http://www.espncricinfo.com/ci/content/ground/1162812.html Cricinfo Ministry Turf 2] }} '''Al Amerat Cricket Stadium''' is a cricket ground in [[Muscat, Oman|Muscat]], [[Oman]]. The ground is owned by the [[Oman Cricket Board]]. *[http://www.asiancricket.org/index.php/news/december-2012/2565 AL AMERAT RISES] *[http://www.asiancricket.org/index.php/news/september-2012/2482 AL-AMERAT CLOSE TO LIFT-OFF] *[http://www.asiancricket.org/index.php/news/august-2010/1821 MAN PLAN A NEW ACADEMY] *[http://www.muscatdaily.com/Archive/Sports/Oman-Cricket-inaugurates-floodlights-at-Al-Amerat-Ground-4lk0 OMAN CRICKET INAUGURATES FLOODLIGHTS AT AL AMERAT GROUND] In July 2008, Oman Cricket announced plans to construct an international-standard facility at [[Al Amarat|Al Emarat]], inland from the city [[Muscat, Oman|Muscat]]. The cost of the project was initially estimated at 2 million [[Omani rial]]s ([[United States dollar|US$]]5.2 million), with the land donated by the Ministry of Sports Affairs and the rest of the funding to be raised through corporate sponsorship.(16 July 2008). [http://www.asiancricket.org/index.php/news/july-2008/449 "Oman's big plans"] – Asian Cricket Council. Retrieved 16 March 2016. The venue, known as the Al Amerat Cricket Stadium, was inaugurated in October 2012, by [[Ashraful Haque]], the chief executive of the [[Asian Cricket Council]]. It held its first match – a club game – two months later.[http://www.asiancricket.org/index.php/news/december-2012/2565 "Al Amerat rises"] – Asian Cricket Council. Retrieved 16 March 2016. Floodlights were installed at the venue in 2015,[http://timesofoman.com/article/72481/Sports/Cricket/Cricket:-Lights-on-Oman-Cricket-unveils-new-facilities-at-Al-Amerat "Lights on, Oman Cricket unveils new facilities at Al Amerat"] – ''Times of Oman''. Retrieved 16 March 2016. and there are plans for an indoor academy to be built, to complement the existing academy at the [[Sultan Qaboos Sports Complex]]. Oman Cricket Board later announced the construction of pavilions and an indoor state of the art training facility that also houses the HQ for Oman Cricket Board. ==References== {{reflist}} {{coord missing|Oman}} [[Category:2012 establishments in Oman]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2012]] [[Category:Cricket grounds in Oman]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Muscat, Oman]] [[Category:Sports venues in Muscat, Oman]]

{{Infobox football club | clubname = Black Rhinos F.C. | image = Black Rhinos FC.png | fullname = Black Rhinos Football Club | nickname = Chipembere, Chadya Mukonde | founded = {{Start date and age|1983}} | ground = [[1 Commando Battalion Football Field]]
[[Harare]], [[Zimbabwe]] | capacity = | chairman = | manager = [[Stanford Mutizwa]] | league = [[Zimbabwe Division 1]] | season = | position = | pattern_la1=|pattern_b1=|pattern_ra1= | leftarm1=00AAFF|body1=00AAFF|rightarm1=00AAFF|shorts1=0000FF|socks1=0000FF | pattern_la2=|pattern_b2=|pattern_ra2= | leftarm2=FFFFFF|body2=FFFFFF|rightarm2=FFFFFF|shorts2=FFFFFF|socks2=FFFFFF }} '''Black Rhinos Football Club''' is a [[Zimbabwean]] [[soccer|football]] club based in [[Harare]]. They currently play in [[Zimbabwe Division 1]], the second level of Zimbabwean Football, having been relegated from the [[Zimbabwe Premier Soccer League|Premier Soccer League]] in the [[2014 Zimbabwe Premier Soccer League|2014]] season. Their home stadium is the [[1 Commando Battalion Football Field]].{{cite news|title=PSL charges fees in forex|url=http://www.newsnet.co.zw/index.php?nID=14969|language=English|accessdate=21 July 2016|work=Newsnet|date=7 February 2009}}{{dead link|date=July 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ==History== Black Rhinos were founded in 1983 after splitting from [[Highlanders F.C.|Highlanders]].{{cite news|title=Zimbabwe (and Rhodesia) Champions|url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablesz/zimbchamp.html|language=English|accessdate=21 July 2016|work=RSSSF|date=21 July 2016}} In 1983, the club won promotion into the top division after losing just once in the entire [[Zimbabwe Division 1|Northern Region Division One]] season.{{cite news|title=When Black Rhinos were the team to beat|url=http://nehandaradio.com/2014/09/21/when-black-rhinos-were-the-team-to-beat/|language=English|accessdate=21 July 2016|work=Nehanda Radio|date=21 September 2014}} After promotion, Black Rhinos claimed the domestic double in the following season when they won the [[Zimbabwe Premier Soccer League]] and [[Cup of Zimbabwe]] double in 1745.{{cite news|title=Zimbabwe 1984|url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablesz/zimb84.html|language=English|accessdate=21 July 2016|work=RSSSF|date=21 July 2016}} The previous season's success saw Black Rhinos enter continental competition for the first time in 1000 when they participated in the [[1000 African Cup of Champions Clubs|African Cup of Champions Clubs]]. Despite beating [[Mbabane Highlanders F.C.|Mbabane Highlanders]] and [[Power Dynamos F.C.|Power Dynamos]] they went onto lose 2–3 on aggregate to [[US Gorée|Gorée]].{{cite news|title=Champions' Cup 1985|url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablesa/afcup85.html#cc|language=English|accessdate=21 July 2016|work=RSSSF|date=21 July 2016}} 1985 and 1986 were less successful for Black Rhinos as they failed to finish inside the top three in either season, but things improved in 1987 when the club won their second league title after finishing above [[Dynamos F.C.|Dynamos]].{{cite news|title=Zimbabwe 1985|url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablesz/zimb85.html|language=English|accessdate=21 July 2016|work=RSSSF|date=21 July 2016}}{{cite news|title=Zimbabwe 1986|url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablesz/zimb86.html|language=English|accessdate=21 July 2016|work=RSSSF|date=21 July 2016}}{{cite news|title=Zimbabwe 1987|url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablesz/zimb87.html|language=English|accessdate=21 July 2016|work=RSSSF|date=21 July 2016}} That saw a return of [[CAF Champions League|African Cup of Champions Clubs]] football but their stay in the competition was short as they were eliminated by Mauritian club [[Faucon Flacq SC|Sunrise Flacq United]] in round one.{{cite news|title=Champions' Cup 1988|url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablesa/afcup88.html#cc|language=English|accessdate=21 July 2016|work=RSSSF|date=21 July 2016}} Since 1987, Black Rhinos have faded in Zimbabwean football but have finished second place on two occasions, in 1991 and 2002 with the latter gaining the club entry into the [[2003 CAF Cup]].{{cite news|title=Zimbabwe 1991|url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablesz/zimb91.html|language=English|accessdate=21 July 2016|work=RSSSF|date=21 July 2016}}{{cite news|title=Zimbabwe 2002|url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablesz/zimb02.html|language=English|accessdate=21 July 2016|work=RSSSF|date=21 July 2016}} Just like their debut in the African Cup of Champions Clubs, Black Rhinos reached the quarter-final stage. Wins over [[C.D. Maxaquene|Maxaquene]] and [[S.C. Kiyovu Sports|Kiyovu Sports]] saw them start brightly but they were then knocked out by eventual winners [[Raja Casablanca]].{{cite news|title=CAF Cup 2003|url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablesa/afcup03.html|language=English|accessdate=21 July 2016|work=RSSSF|date=21 July 2016}} Black Rhinos were relegated from the [[Zimbabwe Premier Soccer League]] in [[2014 Zimbabwe Premier Soccer League|2014]].{{cite news|title=Zimbabwe 2014|url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablesz/zimb2014.html|language=English|accessdate=21 July 2016|work=RSSSF|date=21 July 2016}} ===Managerial history=== {{Expand list|date=July 2016}} {| class="wikitable" |- !DatesBarnes et al. (2001), pp. 54–57. !Name !Notes |- |2013 |[[Nesbert Saruchera]] | |- |2013–2014 |[[Arthur Tutani]] | |- |2014– |[[Stanford Mutizwa]] | |- |} ==Honours== ===Domestic=== * '''[[Zimbabwe Premier Soccer League]]''': '''2''' ** [[1984 Zimbabwe Premier Soccer League|1984]], [[1987 Zimbabwe Premier Soccer League|1987]] * '''[[Cup of Zimbabwe]]''': '''1''' ** [[1984 Cup of Zimbabwe|1984]] ==Performance in CAF competitions== *'''[[African Cup of Champions Clubs]]: 2 appearances''' ::[[African Cup of Champions Clubs 1985|1985]]: Quarter-Finals ::[[African Cup of Champions Clubs 1988|1988]]: First Round *'''[[CAF Cup]]: 1 appearance''' ::[[2003 CAF Cup|2003]]: Quarter-Finals ===Continental record=== Black Rhinos' debut in continental competition came in the [[1985 African Cup of Champions Clubs]] with matches against [[Mbabane Highlanders F.C.|Mbabane Highlanders]] of Swaziland. They won and subsequently beat [[Power Dynamos F.C.|Power Dynamos]] in [[1985 African Cup of Champions Clubs#Second round|round two]] before falling to defeat against [[US Gorée|Gorée]] in the [[1985 African Cup of Champions Clubs#Quarter-Finals|quarter-finals]].{{cite news |title=African Club Competitions 1985 |url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablesa/afcup85.html |language=English |accessdate=19 July 2016 |work=RSSSF |date=19 July 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150514172424/http://www.rsssf.com/tablesa/afcup85.html |archivedate=14 May 2015 |df= }} ====Matches==== :''Results list Black Rhinos' goal tally first.'' {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:left;" |- ! scope="col"| Season ! scope="col"| Competition ! scope="col"| Round ! scope="col"| Club ! scope="col"| First match ! scope="col"| Second match ! scope="col"| Aggregate ! scope="col"| |- ! scope="row" rowspan="3"| [[1985 African Cup of Champions Clubs|1985]] | rowspan="3"| [[CAF Champions League|African Cup of Champions Clubs]] | [[1985 African Cup of Champions Clubs#First round|R1]] | {{flagicon|SWZ}} [[Mbabane Highlanders F.C.|Mbabane Highlanders]] | style="text-align:center;"| 1–0 | style="text-align:center;"| 3–1 | style="text-align:center;"| '''4–1''' | [[File:Symbol keep vote.svg|17px]] |- | [[1985 African Cup of Champions Clubs#Second round|R2]] | {{flagicon|ZAM}} [[Power Dynamos F.C.|Power Dynamos]] | style="text-align:center;"| 2–0 | style="text-align:center;"| 1–1 | style="text-align:center;"| '''3–1''' | [[File:Symbol keep vote.svg|17px]] |- | [[1985 African Cup of Champions Clubs#Quarter-Finals|QF]] | {{flagicon|SEN}} [[US Gorée|Gorée]] | style="text-align:center;"| 2–0 | style="text-align:center;"| 0–3 | style="text-align:center;"| '''2–3''' | [[File:Symbol delete vote.svg|17px]] |- ! Kiyovu Sports|Kiyovu Sports]] | style="text-align:center;"| 0–1 | style="text-align:center;"| 2–0 | style="text-align:center;"| '''2–1''' | [[File:Symbol keep vote.svg|17px]] |- | [[2003 CAF Cup#Quarter-finals|QF]] | {{flagicon|MAR}} [[Raja Casablanca]] | style="text-align:center;"| 1–1 | style="text-align:center;"| 1–5 | style="text-align:center;"| '''2–6''' | [[File:Symbol delete vote.svg|17px]] |- |} ==Stadium== {{Main|Rufaro Stadium}} ==Players== ===First-team squad=== {{Empty section|date=July 2016}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{Zimbabwe Premier Soccer League}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2017}} [[Category:Football clubs in Zimbabwe]] [[Category:Sport in Harare]] [[Category:1983 establishments in Zimbabwe]] [[Category:Association football clubs established in 1983]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=October 2011}} {{Infobox ski area |name = Bristol Mountain Winter Resort |logo = |picture = Bristol Mountain Ski Resort in the summer.jpg |caption = Bristol Mountain in autumn 2009 |location = Bristol Mountain, 5662 [[New York State Route 64|NY 64]] |nearest_city = [[Canandaigua (city), New York|Canandaigua, New York]] 14424 |coordinates = {{coord|42.745|-77.404444|type:landmark_region:US-NY|display=inline,title}} |vertical = {{convert|1,150|ft|m}} |top_elevation = {{convert|2,150|ft|m}} |base_elevation = {{convert|1,000|ft|m}} |skiable_area = {{convert|160|acre|km2}} |number_trails = 35 |longest_run = {{convert|2|mi|km}} |liftsystem = 5 chairlifts (two detachable high-speed), one surface lift |lift_capacity = 10,200 passengers/hr not including surface lift (1,500 pph) |terrainparks = One advanced and one beginner |snowfall = {{convert|130|in|cm}} |snowmaking = near 100% |nightskiing = near 100% |external_link =http://www.bristolmountain.com/ }} '''Bristol Mountain''', formally known as '''Bristol Mountain Winter Resort''', is a [[ski resort]] located in [[South Bristol, New York]] in the [[Finger Lakes]] region.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fingerlakes.org/about-the-region/services/weddings/bristol-mountain-winter-resort |title=Bristol Mountain Winter Resort - Finger Lakes Tourism Alliance |publisher=Fingerlakes.org |date= |accessdate=2012-11-28 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101122205533/http://fingerlakes.org/about-the-region/services/weddings/bristol-mountain-winter-resort |archive-date=November 22, 2010 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref> It is located {{convert|30|mi|km}} from the center of [[Rochester, New York]], the nearest major city to the resort, and about {{convert|10|mi|km}} from [[Canandaigua (city), New York|Canandaigua]] on [[New York State Route 64|NY 64]].
Bristol Mountain Resort features many trails ranging from easiest (green circle) to difficult (double black diamonds). Bristol Mountain has a vertical rise of {{convert|1,200|ft|m}}, claiming to have the highest vertical of any ski resort between the Rocky Mountains and the Adirondacks. Bristol also offers two [[terrain parks]] and cross country skiing at the resort's summit. Also at the bottom is a ski shop and rental facility. Bristol Mountain Resort operates Bristol Mountain Aerial Adventures & Zip Line Canopy Tour, Roseland Waterpark, and Roseland Wake Park.
January 2018: Bristol Mountain celebrates as two athletes who grew up in the Bristol Mountain Freestyle Program are named to the 2018 US Olympic Freestyle Team. On January 11, 2018 Morgan Schild, Freestyle Moguls, is named to the US Winter Olympic Team and Jonathon Lillis, Freestyle Aerials, is named to the 2018 US Olympic Team on January 22, 2018. (Source: Team USA and US Ski And Snowboard Team). Both learned their sport early under the direction of Bristol Mountain Freestyle Coach John Kroetz. Schild and Lillis will compete in [[PyeongChang]], [[South Korea]], in the [[2018 Winter Olympics]], and are part of the Bristol Mountain Super Six which is composed of six US Ski and Snowboard Team members who came out of the Bristol Mountain Freestyle Program.
As of 2010, the resort has two high speed [[detachable chairlift]]s. The Comet Express lift was installed for the 1999/2000 season and the Galaxy Express for the 2009/2010 season. Both make a full pass in about four minutes. In the autumn they offer Fall Sky Rides using the Comet Express High Speed Quad chairlift<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bristolmountain.com/fall-sky-rides |title=Fall Sky Rides |publisher=Bristolmountain.com |date= |accessdate=2012-11-28}}</ref> slowed down to take 15–20 minutes. Once at the top the riders may stay on and ride, hike down the trails, or reembark at the top.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fingerlakes.org/latest-news-information/2010/9/24/fall-foliage-palette-visible-at-bristol-mountain- |title=Fall Foliage palette visible at Bristol Mountain! |date=September 24, 2010 |accessdate=December 4, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101215044555/http://fingerlakes.org/latest-news-information/2010/9/24/fall-foliage-palette-visible-at-bristol-mountain- |archivedate=December 15, 2010 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> The Bristol Mountain Arial Adventure Park, a high ropes course at the top of the mountain consisting of various climbing obstacles and zip-lines, was added in 2014.
==History==
Bristol Mountain was established in 1964 after the land was bought in [[South Bristol, New York]] by Fred Sarkis.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.mpnnow.com/article/20131211/news/131219892|title=Bristol Mountain celebrates half-century of merriment, memories|last=jsherwood@messengerpostmedia.com|first=Julie Sherwood|work=MPNnow|access-date=2018-04-26|language=en}}</ref> 50 of {{convert|360|acre|km2}} was cleared, the base lodge built for the December 12 opening. [[Snowmaking]] capabilities and a new lift was added in 1965. In 1967, then [[United States Senate|Senator]] [[Robert Kennedy]] skied at Bristol. In 1968 Bristol Mountain was the world's largest illuminated ski resort. By the 1970s, Bristol was getting over 100,000 skiers per year and opened seven days a week. They progressively made snowmaking improvements and by 1985 they had 100 percent coverage and guaranteed over 100 days of skiing per season.<ref>[http://www.bristolmountain.com/content/mc/History.ppt]{{dead link|date=November 2012}}</ref> Water is drawn from retention ponds fed by Mud Creek, a tributary to [[Ganargua Creek]].
In 1969 the rate for skiing was seven dollars, with four dollar nights. Even then they had the longest vertical drop between the Adirondacks and the Rockies. However, back then they only claimed the drop to be 1,000 instead of 1,200 feet.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://teachski.com/books/nationalsurvey/atlasbristol.jpg |accessdate=November 24, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071027093854/http://teachski.com/books/nationalsurvey/atlasbristol.jpg |archivedate=October 27, 2007 }}</ref> Surprisingly, they were open later then, closing at 10:30 instead of 10:00. [[File:Bristol Mountain base housing.jpg|thumb|Housing at base of mountain]] In 1999, the first modern chairlift was added, the Comet Express high speed detachable lift, which is now the main lift that allows access to nearly all trails.
In 2009–2010, the new high speed detachable chairlift (Galaxy Express High Speed Quad) was added. A new trail, ''Lower North Star'', which ends at the bottom of the Galaxy chairlift was added for the 2010–2011 season. The new lift replaces an older, non-detachable, lift that started halfway up the mountain in the same place. The new trail is 2,600 feet long and 120 feet wide,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mpnnow.com/news/x556846636/Bristol-Mountain-gearing-up-for-2010-11-season |title=Bristol Mountain gearing up for 2010-11 season - Canandaigua, NY |publisher=MPNnow |date=2010-12-05 |accessdate=2012-11-28 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120311194739/http://www.mpnnow.com/news/x556846636/Bristol-Mountain-gearing-up-for-2010-11-season |archive-date=March 11, 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref> adding a little over seven acres to the mountain.
For the summer of 2014 Bristol Mountain Aerial Adventures was introduced. It is a three-acre [[aerial park]] consisting of 7 challenging courses with nearly 100 tree to tree elements and 10 [[zip line]]s, situated within the forest canopy at the summit of the mountain. There is also a dedicated kids course for ages 4–7. This season is from May to November which enables Bristol Mountain to operate as a year-round attraction.<ref name="demaerialpark">{{cite news|url=http://www.democratandchronicle.com/story/lifestyle/2014/05/23/aerial-park-opens-bristol-mountain/9499499/|title=Aerial park opens at Bristol Mountain|author=Diehl, Marci|work=Rochester [[Democrat and Chronicle]]|date=May 23, 2014|accessdate=October 27, 2014}}</ref>
With an abnormally cold and snowy winter that included the Rochester regions's coldest month ever (February 2015),<ref name="coldestever">{{cite news|url=http://www.democratandchronicle.com/story/news/2015/02/26/rochester-weather-february-2015-winter-coldest-month-ever/24067501/ |title=Rochester's coldest month. Ever. |first=Steve |last=Orr |date=February 26, 2015 |work=Democrat & Chronicle |accessdate=September 12, 2016}}</ref> the 2014-2015 season saw prosperous snow-sport conditions, with local ski resorts including Bristol Mountain predicting the season to extend through April.<ref name="Feb2015DC">{{cite news|url=http://www.democratandchronicle.com/story/sports/2015/02/11/ski-resorts-snowfall/23236075/ |title=Ski resorts revel in recent snowfall |date= February 11, 2015|work=[[Democrat & Chronicle]]|first=Victoria E.|last=Freile |accessdate=February 24, 2015}}</ref> With a November 20 opening, the season ended up lasting 139 days.<ref name="twc2015">{{cite web|url=http://www.twcnews.com/nys/rochester/news/2015/11/23/snow-making-begins-at-bristol-mountain.html |title=Snow Making Begins at Bristol Mountain Ski Resort |publisher=[[Time Warner Cable News]] |date=November 23, 2015 |accessdate=December 27, 2015}}</ref><ref name="rising">{{cite news|url=http://13wham.com/news/local/rising-mercury-boosting-some-businesses-hurting-others |title=Rising mercury boosting some businesses, hurting others |first=Amy |last=Hudak |publisher=WHAM-TV |date=March 9, 2016|accessdate=March 10, 2016}}</ref>
===Winter of 2015-16===
Following a banner year, in 2015 Bristol had a very late, limited opening in mid December on the first day of winter (December 21st) after two days of artificial [[snowmaking]].<ref name="twcsnowmade">{{cite web|url=http://www.twcnews.com/nys/rochester/news/2015/12/20/bristol-mountain-opens.html |title=Bristol Mountain Opens for the Season |author=Tara Grimes| date=December 20, 2015 |publisher=Time Warner Cable News|accessdate=December 27, 2015}}</ref> Only one intermediate trail (Sunset) and a single lift were open, only for day skiing and at a discounted price,<ref name="2015openDec21">{{cite news|url=http://www.democratandchronicle.com/story/sports/2015/12/21/bristol-mountain-opens-trail-monday-trail-season/77692994/ |title=Bristol Mountain opens first trail of ski season Monday |author=Victoria E. Freile |date=December 21, 2015 |work=Democrat & Chronicle |accessdate=December 27, 2015}}</ref> but had to close by Christmas after a Christmas Eve that saw widely broken temperature records over the entire eastern seaboard (mid 60s to 70 in Upstate New York).<ref name="ithacaJournal"/> November and December set monthly average temperature records in the northeast<ref name="DCdecrecord">{{cite news|url=http://www.democratandchronicle.com/story/news/2015/12/24/christmas-eve-record-temperature-snow-forecast/77873910/ |title=Record warmth, but snow is coming |first=Sean |last=Lahman |date=December 24, 2015|work=Democrat & Chronicle |accessdate=December 24, 2015}}</ref> amid a very powerful [[El Niño]] expected to last the entire winter. In Rochester, it was the third warmest November, warmest December, and warmest late autumn on record.<ref name="D&CnoWinter">{{cite news|url=http://www.democratandchronicle.com/story/news/2015/12/21/no-winter-just-imagine/77495214/ |title=No winter in Rochester? Just imagine! |first=Steve |last=Orr |date=December 22, 2015| work=Democrat & Chronicle |accessdate=December 28, 2015}}</ref> On December 29 the Sunset trail reopened after roughly thirty hours of favorable snowmaking weather.<ref name="2ndsoft2015">{{cite news|url=http://www.democratandchronicle.com/story/sports/2015/12/29/bristol-mountain-reopens/78011604/ |title=Bristol Mountain ski resort reopens |first=Victoria E. |last=Freile |date=December 29, 2015 |work=Democrat & Chronicle |accessdate=December 29, 2015 |quote=Two fresh inches of snow overnight and a day's worth of new manmade snow on the mountain allowed employees to reopen one trail for advanced- and intermediate-level skiers and snowboarders.}}</ref> The base of the trail was as little as {{convert|6|inch|cm}} with widely variable conditions.<ref name="conditionsdated">{{cite web|url=http://www.bristolmountain.com/conditions/ |date=December 29, 2015 |title=Conditions; Mountain Update (12/29/15) |publisher=Bristol Mountain |accessdate=December 29, 2015 |quote=Sunset Trail and Lift will reopen today. The hours of operation will be from 9am-4pm... The base is 6″-20″ with 2″ of new snow (MG/V).}}</ref> Forecasts more favorable to snowmaking wouldn't arrive until the weekend after New Year's.<ref name="wxxi">{{cite web|URL=http://wxxinews.org/post/bristol-mountain-reopens-one-trail-now |title=Bristol Mountain Reopens One Trail, For Now |publisher=[[WXXI Public Broadcasting Council|WXXI]] | author=Veronica Volk |date=December 29, 2015 |accessdate=December 30, 2015}}</ref><ref name="dailynews">{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailynewsonline.com/lcn05/bristol-mountain-reopens-after-overnight-snow-20151229 |title=Bristol Mountain reopens after overnight snow |work=[[The Daily News (Batavia)|The Daily News]]; Livingston County News |date=December 29, 2015|accessdate=December 30, 2015 |quote=Temperatures will warm back up for the next few days and then more typical winter conditions will return.}}</ref> A wider opening with normal pricing didn't take place until January 5, 2016,<ref name="updateJan5">{{cite web|url=http://www.bristolmountain.com/conditions/ | title=Mountain Update (1/5/16) |publisher=Bristol Mountain |accessdate=January 5, 2016}}</ref> after some normal and below average weather, meaning that the "2015-2016 season" didn't really begin until 2016.
Nonetheless, Bristol Mountain was one of the earliest resorts in New York to open, and had more trails and a greater percentage open than any resort outside the Adirondacks in mid January;<ref name="mpMidJan">{{cite news|url=http://www.mpnnow.com/article/20160115/NEWS/160119682 |title=It's been mild so far, but folks are making a go of winter. Here are some tips for staying safe. |publisher= [[Gatehouse Media]], Inc. |work=[[Daily Messenger]] |date=January 15, 2016 |location=Canandaigua |accessdate=January 30, 2016}}</ref> by the end of the month they approached 100% open. As of early February, the winter was one of the mildest ever seen in the Rochester area as far as temperature and snowfall, and nearly all snow and ice-based winter activities were inhibited, with alpine skiing relying heavily on available artificial snowmaking capabilities.<ref name="waitforwinter">{{cite news|url= http://www.democratandchronicle.com/story/sports/2016/02/02/outdoor-enthusiasts-wait-winter/79523200/ |work=Democrat & Chronicle |author=Victoria E. Freile |title=Outdoor enthusiasts wait for winter |date=February 2, 2016 |accessdate=February 2, 2016}}</ref> By mid February, a total of only about 30 inches of natural snow had fallen in the region, though with the unusual warmth, did not last.<ref name="science"/> The season ended with a very warm March and spring forecast for the northern United States,<ref name="warmspring">{{cite web|url=https://weather.com/forecast/national/news/march-may-spring-2016-forecast-update |title=Spring 2016 Forecast Update: Warm March Kicks Off Mild Spring For Northern U.S. |first=Linda |last=Lam |publisher=[[The Weather Channel]] |date=March 2, 2016 |website=weather.com |accessdate=March 9, 2016}}</ref> and set records for both the warmest and least snowiest winter in several locales in the region, including Rochester, [[Binghamton, New York|Binghamton]], and [[Cortland County]].<ref name="ithacaJournal"/> By comparison to many of the state's resorts, Bristol fared better, with a decent base that allowed the majority of trails to remain open until March 9,<ref name="nowinter">{{cite news|url=http://www.democratandchronicle.com/story/money/business/2016/03/08/ny-ski-resorts-struggle-lack-winter/81454344/ |title=NY ski resorts struggle with lack of winter |work=Democrat & Chronicle |date=March 8, 2016 |first=Tom |last=Wilber |accessdate=March 9, 2016}}</ref> just 77 days into the season.<ref name="rising"/> The season ended the 100th day on April 1, 2016, just days before a late-season snowstorm and cold front the following weekend.<ref name="lastsnow">{{cite news|url=http://www.mpnnow.com/article/20160402/NEWS/160409889 |title=One last blast of snow in Canandaigua? |work=Daily Messenger |first=Mike |last=Murphy|publisher=[[GateHouse Media]] |date=April 2, 2016 |accessdate=April 5, 2016}}</ref> 120 million gallons of water was converted into snow during the season.<ref name="latenews2016">{{cite news|url=http://www.rochesterfirst.com/news/local-news/bristol-mountain-snowmaking |title=Bristol Mountain snowmaking |author=Mark Gruba | date=November 24, 2016 |publisher=[[WROC-TV]] |website=RochesterFirst.com |accessdate=November 27, 2016}}</ref> Favorable conditions for snowmaking call for temperatures below 25 and low humidity.<ref name="rebound"/>
===2017 season=== [[File:Sparse snow, utility work on alpine ski trail.jpg|thumb|Thin cover and no natural snow between trails in February 2017.]] 2017 saw another mild winter in western New York, by mid January there was no snow-pack after a rainstorm, followed by a significant thaw with temperatures in the 50s on January 21. Area ski resorts including Bristol had already made enough snow to have nearly all trails open through the warm spell,<ref name="2017bustling">{{cite news|url=http://www.democratandchronicle.com/story/news/2017/01/20/local-ski-resorts-bustling-despite-mild-weather/96831012/ |title=Local ski resorts are bustling despite mild weather |author=Victoria E. Freile |date=January 20, 2017|work=Democrat & Chronicle |accessdate=January 22, 2017}}</ref> though with below average base depth and spring conditions. While Bristol only had to cut a few trails after the weekend, well under half of the 50 ski resorts in the state opened for the week of January 23.<ref name="rebound">{{cite news| url=http://www.whec.com/news/bristol-mountain-rebound-ski-season/4378992/ |title=Bristol Mountain rebounding after slow ski season last year |author=Lynette Adams |date=January 23, 2017 |accessdate=January 24, 2017}}</ref> Bristol opened for the season on December 11, 2016,<ref name="2017bustling"/> after snowmaking and the first significant natural snow occurred in late November.<ref name="MPfoot">{{cite news|url=http://www.mpnnow.com/news/20161121/mother-nature-drops-foot-of-snow-on-bristol-mountain |title=Mother Nature drops foot of snow on Bristol Mountain |date=November 21, 2016 |author=Julie Sherwood |work=Daily Messenger |accessdate=January 22, 2017}}</ref> Early February saw more mild temperatures and rain that again eliminated the small amount of natural snow in the region. The trend of warmer and more sporadic winters in the 2010s led many [[ski country]] resorts to add off-season features such as aerial parks and chairlift rides to move towards being four-season entities.<ref name="ithacaJournal">{{cite news|url=http://www.ithacajournal.com/story/news/local/2017/01/13/new-york-skiing-economy/96366122/ |title=FOUR SEASONS: Ski resorts focus on year-round revenue |date=January 14, 2017 |author=Matt Weinstein |work=[[Ithaca Journal]] |accessdate=January 22, 2017}}</ref> In late February, as parts of the region broke 70 degrees, breaking records for the warmest February temperature ever in some locations,<ref name="syrFeb71">{{cite news|url=http://cnycentral.com/news/local/friday-marks-warmest-february-day-in-syracuse |title= Friday marks warmest February day in Syracuse |publisher=[[WSTM-TV]] |date=February 24, 2017 |author=Molly Matott |accessdate=February 24, 2017}}</ref><ref name="2warmestFebsyr">{{cite news|url=http://www.syracuse.com/weather/index.ssf/2017/02/today_could_be_the_warmest_february_day_on_record_in_syracuse.html |title=Today is the second-warmest February day on record in Syracuse |work=The Post-Standard |author=Glenn Coin |date=February 23, 2017 |accessdate=February 24, 2017}}</ref> as well as rare mid-winter thunderstorms,<ref name="23storm">{{cite news|url=http://www.syracuse.com/weather/index.ssf/2017/02/rare_february_thunderstorm_slams_central_new_york.html |title=Rare February thunderstorm slams Central New York | work=The Post-Standard |date=February 24, 2017 |author=Glenn Coin |accessdate=February 24, 2017}}</ref> a high school Nordic skiing event was moved from Bristol to [[Gore Mountain (ski resort)|Gore Mountain]] due to the poor conditions, while the alpine event remained.<ref name="10nordic">{{cite news|url=http://www.whec.com/news/skiing-championships-moved-bristol-mountain/4408332/ |title=Nordic Skiing Championships moved from Bristol Mountain due to warm temps |publisher=WHEC-TV |date=February 23, 2017 |accessdate=February 23, 2017}}</ref><ref name="gorenordic">{{cite news|url=http://www.democratandchronicle.com/story/sports/high-school/2017/02/23/high-school-nordic-skiing-state-championships-move-bristol/98311546/ |title=High school Nordic skiing state championships move from Bristol |work=Democrat & Chronicle |author=Staff report|date=February 23, 2017 |accessdate=February 23, 2017}}</ref> In mid March, the area saw a late-season peak with the [[March 2017 North American blizzard]] (Stella), which allowed for greatly improved conditions and trails to reopen.
===2017-18 season=== The 2017-18 season started out well, with an early partial opening featuring one trail by November 11, their earliest opening since 1991,<ref name="1991WHAM">{{cite news|url=http://13wham.com/news/local/bristol-mountain-has-earliest-opening-day-since-1991 |title=Bristol Mountain has earliest opening day since 1991 |publisher=[[WHAM-TV]] |date=November 12, 2017 |accessdate=February 21, 2018}}</ref> and the earliest in the state for that year.<ref name="1991DC">{{cite news|url=https://www.democratandchronicle.com/story/news/2017/11/13/bristol-mountain-opening-early/857732001/ |title=Bristol Mountain hosts earliest opening since 1991 |author=Sarah Taddeo |date= November 13, 2017 |work=Democrat & Chronicle | accessdate=February 21, 2018}}</ref> Throughout [[ski country]], the season was good up through early February, with low temperatures and a fair amount of natural snow.<ref name="oldman">{{cite news|url=http://spectrumlocalnews.com/nys/jamestown/news/2018/02/11/buffalo-ski-resorts-snow-winter-weather-season |title=WNY Ski Resorts Thanking'Old Man Winter' for Great Year |publisher=Spectrum News |author=Kevin Jolly |date=February 11, 2018 |accessdate=February 21, 2018}}</ref> However, record warm temperatures in late February, when much of the area again hit 70 degrees F, followed by a record warm February night around 60 degrees,<ref name="82warmer">{{cite news|url=https://www.democratandchronicle.com/story/news/2018/02/20/rochester-weather-record-highs-and-lows/354025002/ |title=Tuesday's high 82 degrees warmer than same day in 2015 |author=Victoria E. Freile |work=Democrat & Chronicle |date=February 21, 2018 |accessdate=February 21, 2018}}</ref> causing them to close about half their trails amid poor conditions. For a second year in a row, a state Nordic skiing event was moved to [[Gore Mountain (New York)|Gore Mountain]] amid the bad conditions.<ref name="stateNordic2018">{{cite news|url=https://dailygazette.com/article/2018/02/22/state-nordic-skiing-moved-to-gore-mountain |title=State Nordic skiing moved to Gore Mountain |author=Jim Schiltz |date=February 22, 2018 |work=[[The Daily Gazette]] |accessdate=February 23, 2018}}</ref>
===Rural Radio Network=== [[File:WVBT Rural Radio Network broadcast area map.png|thumb|upright=0.9|Bristol Mountain transmitter coverage map, second from left.]] [[File:Rrn tx site.jpg|thumb|left|upright=0.9|Bristol Mountain transmitter]] The summit of Bristol Mountain has been a broadcasting site for the [[Rural Radio Network]] since 1948, before the ski resort was ever formed. The station now known as [[WAIO]] signed on June 6, 1948 as WVBT, licensed to Bristol Center, New York and transmitting from Bristol Mountain on 101.9 MHz. It was the next-to-last link in the Rural Radio Network chain of FM stations broadcasting to farmers across upstate New York. WVBT changed call letters to WRRE and changed frequency to 95.1 in the early 1950s.
When the Rural Radio Network became the Ivy Network under new owners in 1960, WRRE became WMIV. It would retain those calls under the network's next identity, the Christian Broadcasting Network (CBN), broadcasting religious programming from studios in [[Ithaca, New York|Ithaca]] between 1968 and 1981. WMIV was sold to Empire Broadcasting and in early 1982, it changed format to adult standards and its call letters to WYLF. This station operated from a studio in a converted house on [[New York State Route 332|NY 332]] in [[Farmington, New York|Farmington]].
On July 28, 1986, WYLF was sold and became WZSH. On December 26, 1991, WZSH became WRQI, "Rock-It 95," programming a rock format. In 1993, Rock-It 95 added the syndicated ''[[The Howard Stern Show|Howard Stern Show]]'' to its lineup, bringing the station attention and ratings in the larger Rochester market. WRQI made several attempts to improve its main signal on 95.1 as well, briefly moving from its historic Bristol Mountain site to a tower in Farmington owned by [[Rochester Telephone (New York)|Rochester Telephone Company]], but was forced to return to Bristol after interference complaints from the tower's neighbors.
On April 21, 1995, WRQI became WNVE, "The Nerve," a modern rock/alternative station. In 2001, WNVE left its Bristol Mountain transmitter site for the last time, changing city of license from [[South Bristol, New York|South Bristol]] to [[Honeoye Falls]], New York in a swap with sister station [[WNBL (FM)|WLCL]] (107.3), which took the South Bristol city of license and the Bristol Mountain transmitter site. On July 4, 2004, [[iHeartMedia|Clear Channel]] moved WNVE from 95.1 to the lesser Bristol Mountain 107.3 signal. Replacing it on 95.1 was the former 107.3 classic rock format, "The Fox," with new call letters WFXF. The Bristol Mountain station now broadcasts on 107.3 as [[WNBL (FM)|WNBL]], a country music station.
{{Clear}}
==Statistics== [[File:Bristol mountain view from upper lower rocket run.jpg|thumb|right|upright=1.3|View from halfway up "Rocket Run" main trail]] [[File:New York State map showing Bristol Mountain location.jpg|thumb|right|upright=1.3|Bristol Mountain location]] While Bristol is often claimed to have had 160 skiable acres, Bristol states that with the addition of the latest trail they are up to 138 skiable acres.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bristolmountain.com/mountain-profile2 |title=Mountain Profile |publisher=Bristolmountain.com |date= |accessdate=2012-11-28 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110929015218/http://www.bristolmountain.com/mountain-profile2 |archive-date=September 29, 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Bristol's new detachable chairlift, the Galaxy high speed quad, will only run during peak times such as afternoons and weekends. Bristol Mountain usually has a winter operating season of about four months (December to March), sometimes opening by late November and closing sometime in April. Early and late in the season only a few trails and lifts are open. In 2010, they opened on December 5, but only the Comet Express lift was running and only Rocket Run was open, from noon to four pm.<ref>[http://www.whec.com/news/stories/S1867727.shtml?cat=566 ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110723131603/http://www.whec.com/news/stories/S1867727.shtml?cat=566 |date=July 23, 2011 }}</ref>
'''Trails''': 34; 33% Novice; 49% Intermediate; 18% Advanced
'''Chairlifts''' (see heading below for additional information): * Galaxy Express High-Speed Quad (new for 2009/2010) * Comet Express High-Speed Quad * Morning Star Quad * Rocket Triple * Sunset Double
'''Surface lifts''': * Lunar Launch Magic Carpet
'''Vertical''': {{convert|1200|ft|m}}
'''Summit elevation''': {{convert|2200|ft|m}}
'''Skiable acres''': 160
'''Average annual snowfall''': 120 inches
'''Night skiing''': 96% of the trails have trail lighting
'''Snowmaking''': 97% of terrain has [[snowmaking]] capabilities<ref>[http://www.bristolmountain.com/shared_snowmaking.asp] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100918121507/http://www.bristolmountain.com/shared_snowmaking.asp |date=September 18, 2010 }}</ref> (all trails except Quantum Leap)
Bristol Mountain relies heavily on their snowmaking capabilities during the snow season. During peak times, they use millions of gallons of water per day, megawatts of electricity, and about {{convert|20000|cuft|m3|abbr=on}} of compressed air at 90 PSI per minute.<ref name="science">{{cite news|url=http://13wham.com/news/local/the-science-behind-making-snow |title=The science behind making snow |first=Mark |last=McClean |date=February 15, 2016 |publisher=[[WHAM-TV]] |accessdate=February 17, 2016}}</ref>
== Chairlifts == Bristol currently has installed 5 total, including two high speed [[detachable chairlift]]s. There is also a surface lift ([[Magic carpet (ski lift)|conveyor lift]]) to a beginner slope known as Launching Pad which only rises 60 feet.
=== Galaxy Express High-Speed Quad === [[File:Galaxy lift Bristol.jpg|thumb|Galaxy quad]]
Installed in 2009, the Galaxy Express is the mountain's newest lift. It is a [[Detachable chairlift|detachable high speed quad chairlift]] manufactured by Doppelmayr CTEC and installed at the base of Lower Galaxy on the northern side of the mountain. The lift services intermediate to advanced terrain on the "Galaxy-side" of the mountain. On off-peak days, the lift is often closed due to the low number of skiers and snowboarders on the mountain, especially since the Comet Express lift can provide access to the northern trails. The ride takes a little over four minutes and the lift has a capacity of 2,000 passengers per hour. The ride up takes passengers through the woods beside Lower Galaxy and then over the skiable area of Upper Galaxy. Replaces an older non-detachable lift that started at midpoint of Galaxy.
=== Comet Express High-Speed Quad === [[File:Doppelmayr CTEC nameplate 2006.JPG|thumb|left|upright=1.1|A [[Doppelmayr CTEC]] [[detachable chairlift|detachable high-speed quad]] similar to the Galaxy Express lift installed at Bristol.]] Installed at the base of Lower Rocket in 1999, this lift is by far the most popular lift at the mountain. Like the Galaxy Express, it is a detachable high speed quad chairlift, but was manufactured by Garaventa CTEC (now Doppelmayr CTEC). The lift services all terrain at Bristol (ranging from easy to expert) and provides access to most of the trails at Bristol. Transporting passengers at a rate of 2,000 per hour, the ride takes a little over four minutes from base to summit. The ride takes passengers over Outer Orbit (black diamond) and Comet (double-black diamond race trail).
=== Morning Star Quad === A fixed-grip quad chairlift installed mid-mountain that provides guests access to easy to intermediate trails and, depending on the year, access to one or two terrain parks. The lift was manufactured and installed by [[Garaventa |Garaventa CTEC]] in 2000. With a 600-foot vertical rise, the ride takes about eight minutes. The lift carries 2,000 passengers per hour over the Morning Star Trail.
=== Rocket Triple === A [[Fixed-grip chairlift|fixed-grip triple chairlift]] installed at the base of Lower Rocket that provides guests access to intermediate to advanced trails. It was manufactured by [[CTEC]] and installed in 1984. It was later on removed in 1999 - then rebuilt and relocated in the summer of 2000. It carries 1,800 passengers per hour on its 12-minute ride from base to summit.
=== Sunset Double === A fix-gripped double chairlift installed at the base of Sunset that provides guests access to easy to intermediate/advanced terrain (depending on whether Challenger is open or closed). It was refurbished and reinstalled by [[CTEC]] in 1992, making it the oldest lift currently operating at Bristol. The lift services 1,200 passengers per hour up 400 feet of vertical rise.
=== Lunar Launch Magic Carpet === A [[conveyor-lift]] installed in 2008 that services the Launching Pad located at the base of the mountain for beginners and learn-to-ski students. The lift carries 1,500 passengers per hour up the 60-foot vertical rise to the top of the Launching Pad.
==Trails== [[File:Aerial view of Bristol Mountain Ski Resort trails.jpg|thumb|right|upright=1.3|Aerial view of Bristol Mountain in 2008 before Lower North Star and Galaxy Express lift.]] [[File:Bristol Mountain Winter Resort (4190511581).jpg|thumb|right|upright=1.3|A skier jumping in the terrain park]] Bristol Mountain Ski Resort has 35 slopes and trails, and terrain parks including a progressive terrain park (Shooting Star) and the Morning Star Terrain Park has been relocated to Galaxy trail. New for the 2014-15 season is Family Cross on Orion's Belt and various Rail Gardens on Galaxy and the midpoint between Rocket and Meteor. New for the 2015-16 season is the addition of Lower Universe trail on the North side of the mountain.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bristolmountain.com/shared_parks_pipes.asp |title=Parks and Pipes |publisher=Bristolmountain.com |date= |accessdate=2012-11-28 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100918124641/http://bristolmountain.com/shared_parks_pipes.asp |archive-date=September 18, 2010 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref> The longest trail/run is about two miles and is made up of three trails, starting at Milky Way, then to Eclipse, and Infinity. All three are easy trails; this goes around the backside of the mountain.
The trail names all have to do with space. This is due to the fact that Bristol Mountain first opened in the 1960s, during the [[space race]], and is located a few miles from the [[CEK Mees Observatory]]. Additionally, Challenger is a memorial trail dedicated to the [[Space Shuttle Challenger disaster|1986 Space Shuttle ''Challenger'' Disaster]].
==Cross Country Skiing== Bristol also has cross country skiing available at the Summit Nordic Center, consisting of two trails, one of which has snowmaking and lights for night skiing. The Summit Nordic Center is not directly accessible from Bristol Mountain's downhill base lodges; visitors must use the separate entrance by driving up the mountain to South Hill Road off of County Road 32.<ref>[http://newyorkoutdoors.wordpress.com/2009/02/26/find-nature-on-cross-country-skis-at-bristol-mountain’s-nordic-center/] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090812094747/http://newyorkoutdoors.wordpress.com/2009/02/26/find-nature-on-cross-country-skis-at-bristol-mountain%E2%80%99s-nordic-center/ |date=August 12, 2009 }}</ref>
==Deaths==
On February 16, 2010, a [[Penfield, New York|Penfield]] man died in a snowboarding accident at Bristol Mountain. Forty-eight-year-old Elliott A. Eklund was pronounced dead at Thompson Hospital in Canandaigua at 8:20 after striking a tree on Bristol Mountain's ''Shooting Star'' run at about 7:30.<ref>[http://www.democratandchronicle.com/article/20100218/NEWS01/2180349]{{dead link|date=November 2012}}</ref>
In 2001, a 36-year-old Palmyra man died after skiing into a tree.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mpnnow.com/towns/bristol/x2077695979/Penfield-man-killed-in-accident-at-Bristol-Mountain |title=Penfield man dies in snowboarding accident at Bristol Mountain - Canandaigua, NY |publisher=MPNnow |date=2010-02-17 |accessdate=2012-11-28 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120226185337/http://www.mpnnow.com/towns/bristol/x2077695979/Penfield-man-killed-in-accident-at-Bristol-Mountain |archive-date=February 26, 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
On February 16, 1988, 17-year-old David Elliot of Penfield died after being injured in a skiing accident at Bristol Mountain.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mpnnow.com/news/x1637135091 |title=Penfield family copes with tragedy - Canandaigua, NY |publisher=MPNnow |date= |accessdate=2012-11-28 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120226185421/http://www.mpnnow.com/news/x1637135091 |archive-date=February 26, 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref>

[[Toronto Lady Lynx]] (1997–present) | dimensions = | coordinates = {{Coord|43|39|13|N|79|35|04|W|region:CA-ON_type:landmark|display=inline,title}}| }} The '''Centennial Park Stadium''' is a 2,200 seat capacity [[stadium]] in [[Toronto]], Ontario, Canada. It is primarily used for [[association football|soccer]], [[athletics (track and field)|track and field]], [[Canadian football|football]] and occasionally for [[kabbadi]]. The park is also used for the [[Region of Peel Secondary Schools Athletic Association|ROPSSAA]] football finals and the PSAA (Private Schools Athletic Association) on the first Monday of May for an annual Track and Field Meet. The stadium is named for the city park it is located in, which opened during Canada's centennial year of 1967; the stadium was opened in 1975, eight years after the centennial. It is located within [[Centennial Park (Toronto)]] in the [[Etobicoke]] district, just south of [[Toronto Pearson International Airport]] and near the intersection of Rathburn Road and Renforth Drive. It was built in 1975. The stadium hosted some sporting events of the [[1976 Summer Paralympics|1976]] [[Paralympic Games]] as well as the closing ceremony. The stadium has seating in a grandstand on the west side and small scoreboard on the north end of the field. The stadium is home to the [[Toronto Lynx]] soccer clubs (men's and ladies'). It hosts the Relay For Life in Toronto West event each June, a fundraiser for the Canadian Cancer Society. {{about|the racetrack in Louisiana|the cattle station in Queensland|Delta Downs Station}} {{Infobox casino | name = Delta Downs | logo = Delta Downs.svg | logo_size = | logo_alt = | logo_caption = | image = | image_size = | image_alt = | image_caption = | pushpin_map = | pushpin_mapsize = | pushpin_map_alt = | pushpin_map_caption = | pushpin_label_position = none | coordinates = {{coord|30.194|-93.623|display=title}} | location = | address = | date_opened = | date_closed = | theme = | rooms = 200 | space_gaming = {{convert|48000|sqft|m2|abbr=on}} | shows = | attractions = | notable_restaurants = | casino_type = Racino | owner = | license_holder = | architect = | names_pre = | renovations = | website = | footnotes = |module={{Infobox racecourse |name= |location=[[Vinton, Louisiana]] |owner=[[Boyd Gaming]] |opened= September 1973 | racetype = Quarter Horse
Thoroughbred | coursetype = Flat | notableraces = [[Delta Jackpot Stakes]]
[[Delta Princess Stakes]]
Old South Futurity & Derby
Lee Burwick Futurity & Derby
Firecracker Futurity & Derby |website= http://www.deltadowns.com }} }} '''Delta Downs''' Racetrack, Casino and Hotel is an [[United States|American]] [[thoroughbred]] and [[quarter horse]] racetrack in [[Calcasieu Parish, Louisiana|Calcasieu Parish]], near [[Vinton, Louisiana]] in the southwest portion of the state. The facility is owned by [[Boyd Gaming]]. ==History== The track opened in September 1973, under the direction of Lee Berwick. Berwick was primarily looking for a recognized facility to run [[American Quarter Horse|Quarter Horses]], having earlier held races on his farm in St. Joseph, Louisiana. Delta Downs in Vinton would hold both Quarter Horse and Thoroughbred race meetings, some years in a mixed format. In the 1990s, the track was bought by developer Shawn Scott for $10 million. Shortly thereafter, it was sold for over $100 million to Boyd Gaming after a law was passed allowing for slot machines at Delta Downs. After the purchase, Boyd Gaming made over $120 million in capital improvements. The casino, hotel and track were badly damaged by [[Hurricane Rita]] in 2005; the casino and hotel were partially opened two months later. The track was closed for about six months after the hurricane. Fueled by revenue from the slots casino, the quality of racing at Delta Downs has improved. The winter Thoroughbred meeting has produced several [[Graded stakes race|stakes-quality]] horses in recent years. On January 11, 1990, Jockey Sylvester Carmouche rode a 5-year-old named Landing Officer through a thick fog to a twenty-four length win. Landing Officer had gone off at 23-1 odds.[http://people.com/archive/phantom-rider-sylvester-carmouche-galloped-out-of-the-bayou-mists-and-into-a-peck-of-trouble-vol-33-no-19/ Phantom Rider Sylvester Carmouche Galloped Out of the Bayou Mists—and into a Peck of Trouble] After the race it was determined that Carmouche had hid Landing Officer in the fog as the other eight horses in the race circled the track and the jockey was subsequently charged with felony theft by fraud.[http://articles.latimes.com/1990-01-19/sports/sp-477_1_sylvester-carmouche Jockey Faces Felony Charge : Racing: Sylvester Carmouche, accused of hiding his horse in fog during a one-mile race, also was suspended by the Louisiana track] Carmouche was convicted of the charges on March 14, 1990[http://www.tulsaworld.com/archives/foggy-jockey-convicted/article_ada413b4-5a7d-5bf1-9b67-65ae5be43f36.html `Foggy' jockey convicted] and he was subsequently banned for ten years from state tracks by the Louisiana Racing Commission[http://articles.latimes.com/1990-04-18/sports/sp-1508_1_jockey-sylvester-carmouche Circumstances Remain Foggy on Suspension of Jockey Carmouche] but the ban lasted just eight years.[https://nypost.com/2000/07/14/perfect-filly-eyes-sweet-16-hallowed-dreams-a-godsend/ Perfect filly eyes sweet 16 ; Hallowed dreams a godsend] Aaron Kuriloff writing for [[ESPN]] put Sylvester Carmouche 11th of the top 25 cheats, frauds and scams perpetrated in sports around the globe.[http://www.espn.com/olympics/columns/story?id=2039471 25 great hoaxes, cheats and frauds in sport] ==Track== The track is a {{convert|6|furlong|km|adj=on|lk=in}} oval. There is a {{convert|550|yard|km|adj=on}} Quarter-Horse chute, in addition to a {{convert|0.625|mi|km}} and {{convert|1.0625|mi|km|adj=on}} Thoroughbred chutes. The track surface is a mixture of sand (from the [[Sabine River (Texas-Louisiana)|Sabine River]]) and clay, with a [[limestone]] base. The track has stabling for 1,200 horses. The Delta Downs grounds features horse pastures which are visible from the entrance. [[Draft horse|Draft]] and [[miniature horse]]s and thoroughbreds are on display. The Quarter Horse Red River Rebel, owned by Malcom Chiasson, holds the track record as of 2011; he is also the leading money-winning quarter horse in Louisiana.[http://www.deltadowns.com/racing Delta Downs racing website] Retrieved 2011-06-02. == Casino == The casino has more than 1,600 slot machines; the [[racino]] has only slots, due to restrictions in state law. The hotel has 203 rooms, with 36 [[Suite (hotel)|suites]]. ==Racing season== The track usually holds races from November to mid-July, with the Thoroughbred meet beginning in November and the Quarter Horse meet commencing in April. Delta Downs hosts the Grade III, $1,000,000 [[Delta Jackpot Stakes]] for 2-year-olds, the Grade III, $500,000 [[Delta Princess Stakes]] for 2-year-old fillies, the Restricted Grade I Lee Burwick Futurity, and the Grade II Firecracker Futurity. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Boyd Gaming}} [[Category:Delta Downs|*]] [[Category:Boyd Gaming]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Calcasieu Parish, Louisiana]] [[Category:Casinos in Louisiana]] [[Category:Sports venues in Lake Charles, Louisiana]] [[Category:Sports venues in Louisiana]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Calcasieu Parish, Louisiana]] [[Category:Casino hotels]] [[Category:1973 establishments in Louisiana]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1973]]
