[[Basketball]]: 14,300
[[Ice hockey]]: 14,000 | publictransit = [[Providence Station]] }} The '''Dunkin' Donuts Center''' (originally '''Providence Civic Center''') is an [[indoor arena]] located in downtown [[Providence, Rhode Island]]. It was built in 1972, as a home court for the emerging [[Providence Friars men's basketball|Providence College men's basketball]] program, due to the high demand for tickets to their games in [[Alumni Hall (Providence)|Alumni Hall]], as well as for a home arena for the then-[[Providence Reds]], who played in the nearly 50-year-old [[Rhode Island Auditorium]]. Current tenants include the [[Providence Bruins]], of the [[American Hockey League|AHL]] and the Providence College men's basketball team. ==Background== The idea for a Civic Center in Providence had been proposed as early as 1958, on the site of what later became the [[Providence Place Mall]]. The project was proposed as a joint federal-state-city project, which would create jobs and bring economic benefits. However, the plan failed due to the inability to secure federal funds.{{cite book|last1=Leazes|first1=Francis J|last2=Motte|first2=Mark T.|title=Providence, the Renaissance City|date=2004|publisher=UPNE|pages=60–61|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XKrdcn_xcIcC&pg=PA61&lpg=PA61&dq=providence+voters+reject+civic+center&source=bl&ots=bC4dfJgxAq&sig=7mCfqRNinYDtcabre_j6N_wQKyY&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj76rTyl73QAhUW3YMKHX3XAtsQ6AEIITAB#v=onepage&q=providence%20voters%20reject%20civic%20center&f=false|accessdate=22 November 2016}} The plan was revived again as a statewide bond issue in the 1968 general election; voters outside of Providence soundly defeated the referendum. Finally, mayor [[Joseph A. Doorley Jr.]] pushed through a citywide special referendum in 1969, which passed. When this amount proved to be inadequate, Doorley pushed through another referendum in 1971, which also passed. The project became so closely associated with Mayor Doorley that it was referred to in the press as "Doorley's Dream."{{cite web|title=Mayors of the City of Providence|url=http://www.providenceri.com/CityHall/mayors8.html|website=City of Providence|accessdate=22 November 2016}} ==History== The '''Providence Civic Center''' was constructed in 1972 on the site of an old jewelry factory.{{cite news|last1=Stanton|first1=Mike|title=A Providence civics lesson|url=http://www.providencejournal.com/news/20140626/providence-civics-lesson|accessdate=22 November 2016|publisher=The Providence Journal|date=9 December 2002}} The opening ceremony was held November 3, 1972, with a [[Providence Reds]] hockey game. President [[Richard Nixon]], campaigning in the area, was invited to the attend the opening, but he declined. In its first year, the center hosted concerts by [[Pink Floyd]] and [[Frank Sinatra]], as well as hockey games and political rallies, and was considered a success. In October 1974, Civic Center director Harold Copeland was convicted of soliciting a $1,000 bribe from a concert promoter. The conviction, occurring a month before election day, thrust prosecutor [[Buddy Cianci|Vincent Cianci]] into the Mayor's office and ended Doorley's political career. In the 1980s and 1990s, the Civic Center fell into decline; it required city bailouts and was seen as a financial problem. The [[Rhode Island Convention Center]] and adjacent [[Omni Providence Hotel]] (then named the "Westin") were completed next door to the Civic Center in 1993 in an attempt to lure visitors to the city. In 2001, as a means of increasing financing, the arena was named the Dunkin' Donuts Center as part of a naming-rights deal with [[Dunkin' Donuts]].{{cite press release |title=Providence Civic Center and Dunkin' Donuts Seal a Sweet Deal|url=https://www.dunkindonuts.com/aboutus/press/PressRelease.aspx?viewtype=archive&id=100013|publisher=Dunkin' Donuts Incorporated|date=June 14, 2001|accessdate=September 20, 2005|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060321023750/https://www.dunkindonuts.com/aboutus/press/PressRelease.aspx?viewtype=archive&id=100013|archivedate=March 21, 2006}} In December 2005, the Rhode Island Convention Center Authority purchased the building from the city of Providence and spent $80 million on an extensive renovation. Major elements of the construction included a significantly expanded lobby and concourse, an enclosed pedestrian bridge from the Rhode Island Convention Center, a new center-hung [[LED]] video display board, a new restaurant, 20 luxury suites, four new bathrooms, and all-new seats with cupholders in the arena bowl. Behind-the-scenes improvements included a new [[HVAC]] system, ice chiller, and a first-of-its-kind fire suppression system. These renovations were completed in October 2008.{{cite news |title=Renovations a Slam Dunk|first=Paul Edward|last=Parker|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/projo/doc/397839283.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Aug+31%2C+2008&author=Parker%2C+Paul+Edward&pub=The+Providence+Journal&edition=&startpage=&desc=Renovations+a+slam+Dunk|newspaper=[[The Providence Journal]]|date=August 31, 2008|accessdate=June 10, 2014|page=F1}} ==Notable performances and events== ===Music=== The [[Grateful Dead]] recorded half of their live album, entitled ''[[Dick's Picks Volume 12]]'', here on June 26, 1974. Former Beatle [[George Harrison]] held a concert here on December 11, 1974, during his "[[George Harrison and Ravi Shankar's 1974 North American tour|Dark Horse Tour]]" (so called because it occurred near the launch of Harrison's [[Dark Horse Records]]). Performers included Harrison, [[Ravi Shankar]], [[Jim Keltner]], and [[Billy Preston]]. At one point in the show, a girl tried to climb onstage, but was stopped and assaulted by police; Harrison stopped mid-song and shouted "Krishna! Krishna!". Some of the songs on the [[Eric Clapton]] album ''[[E. C. Was Here]]'' were recorded live at the Civic Center, on June 25, 1975. The arena played host to The [[Rolling Thunder Revue]] Tour on November 4, 1975, headed by [[Bob Dylan]]. [[The Who]] played here on December 13, 1975. [[Elvis Presley]] performed there three times – once each in 1974, 1976, and 1977. [[Frank Sinatra]] performed 10 times at the then-Providence Civic Center. His first was to a sold-out crowd including [[Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis]] for his Variety Club International Tour on April 15, 1974 and the last on October 3, 1992. During many of Sinatra's performances, Rhode Island State Police would attend, searching for organized crime members in the audience. During a 1979 appearance in Providence, Mayor [[Buddy Cianci]] named Sinatra an honorary fire chief, complete with a helmet bearing the name "F. SINATRA" with nickname "Ol' Blue Eyes" beneath. [[David Bowie]]'s concert on May 5, 1978 was one of three recorded for his live album ''[[Stage (David Bowie album)|Stage]]''. The [[Bee Gees]] performed two sold-out concerts here on August 28–29, 1979 as part of their [[Spirits Having Flown Tour]]. [[The Kinks]] recorded much of their live album and video, ''[[One for the Road (The Kinks album)|One for the Road]]'' at the Civic Center September 23, 1979. In 1979, Providence mayor Buddy Cianci cancelled a concert at the Civic Center by the rock band [[The Who]].{{cite news|last1=Grow|first1=Kory|title=Meet the Who Fans Who Found Their Cancelled 1979 Concert Tickets|url=http://www.spin.com/2012/08/meet-who-fans-who-found-their-canceled-1979-concert-tickets/|accessdate=22 November 2016|publisher=SPIN magazine|date=1 August 2012}} Cianci cancelled the performance after hearing about a [[The Who concert disaster|Who concert in Cincinnati]] earlier that month where 11 fans had been trampled to death. 33 years later, the band [[The Who Tour 2012–2013|returned to Providence]] and announced they would honor any tickets from the 1979 show. Ten fans, now middle-aged, traded in 14 tickets to see the performance. In 1979 [[Kiss (band)|Kiss]] scheduled a show on their [[Dynasty Tour]] for August 1, 1979, and a second show was added for July 31, 1979 when the first date sold out. Both were threatened with cancellation by Cianci in light of The Who situation and a stabbing at a Bad Company concert ten days prior to the first date. After controversy, which included rock fans picketing the Cianci's home, the shows were allowed and Cianci attended the first night's performance to observe.The Providence Journal Bulletin, August 1, 1979 "KISS erupts in noise and smoke: Wary officials prowl Civic Center as decible count zooms." The Civic Center also received publicity in 1983 for a planned Kiss concert which never occurred. Rhode Island promoter Frank J. Russo scheduled the band on their [[Creatures of the Night Tour/10th Anniversary Tour]] for shows at both the Worcester Centrum on January 22, 1983 and the following night at the Civic Center, but canceled the Civic Center show when it sold only 2,000 tickets. Russo publicly offered to trade tickets to the Centrum show for Civic Center show tickets in lieu of refunds, with a free ride to and from Worcester. Hundreds of fans participated and were picked up by several chartered buses on Sabin Street in front of the Civic Center.Providence Journal Bulletin January 21, 1983 "KISS is Back: 'We're Like An Army.'" A week later the situation was featured in a two-part WPRI Channel 12 news story by reporter Brian Rooney,https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xIa7qHY1YAs citing it as a prime example of how the newly built Centrum was cutting deeply into the Civic Center's business by providing aggressive competition for events. [[Phish]] have performed at the venue several times, and three of their concerts there have been released on compact disc: ''[[Live Phish Volume 20]]'' features the band's concert of December 29, 1994, and ''[[Live Phish 04.04.98]]'' and ''[[Live Phish 04.05.98]]'' feature the band's performances on April 4 and 5, 1998, which were part of their 1998 "Island Tour". ===Sports=== ====Providence College men's basketball==== The [[Providence Friars men's basketball]] team has been the only major tenant of the arena since its inception, having played almost all of its home basketball games at the arena since 1972. The Providence men's basketball team and their fans have made the Dunk one of the most intimidating environments in recent years for NCAA basketball. On rare occasions, the Providence women's basketball team has played "home" games in the arena, most notably for games against URI or the [[University of Connecticut]], where demand for tickets would be enough to warrant an arena larger than the 1,854-seat Alumni Hall. ====Other college sports==== The arena has been the site of many collegiate tournaments, including the inaugural 1980 [[Big East Conference (1979–2013)|Big East Conference]] men's basketball tournament; the [[NCAA Division I|Division I]] men's basketball [[ECAC Men's Basketball Tournaments|ECAC New England Region Tournament]], organized by the [[Eastern College Athletic Conference]] (ECAC), in [[ECAC Men's Basketball Tournaments#1978 Tournaments|1978]] and [[ECAC Men's Basketball Tournaments#1979 Tournaments|1979]];{{cite web|title=ECAC Men's Basketball Tournaments |url=http://jonfmorse.com/wiki/index.php?title=ECAC_Men%27s_Basketball_Tournaments |work=Varsity Pride |accessdate=June 10, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131224112258/http://jonfmorse.com/wiki/index.php?title=ECAC_Men's_Basketball_Tournaments |archivedate=December 24, 2013 |df= }}{{cite web|title=1978 ECAC Men's Basketball Tournaments |url=http://jonfmorse.com/wiki/index.php?title=1978_ECAC_Men%27s_Basketball_Tournaments |work=Varsity Pride |accessdate=June 10, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131214112326/http://jonfmorse.com/wiki/index.php?title=1978_ECAC_Men's_Basketball_Tournaments |archivedate=December 14, 2013 |df= }}{{cite web |title=1979 ECAC Men's Basketball Tournaments|url=http://jonfmorse.com/wiki/index.php?title=1979_ECAC_Men%27s_Basketball_Tournaments|work=Varsity Pride|accessdate=June 10, 2014}}{{cite web |title=1978–79 Independent Season Summary|url=https://www.sports-reference.com/cbb/conferences/independent/1979.html|work=Sports-Reference|accessdate=June 10, 2014}} [[NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament]] first- and second-round games in [[1976 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament|1976]], [[1979 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament|1979]], [[1980 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament|1980]], [[1981 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament|1981]], [[NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament|1989]], [[1996 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament|1996]], [[2010 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament|2010]], and [[2016 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament|2016]]; the [[1978 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament|1978]] and [[1985 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament|1985]] NCAA Division I Men's Basketball Tournament East Region finals; the inaugural 1985 [[Hockey East]] Tournament, as well as the second tournament a year later in 1986 before the tourney made [[Boston]] a permanent home; and the 1978, 1980, 1982, 1986, 1995 and 2000 NCAA [[Frozen Four]] ice hockey championships. The [[University of Rhode Island]] (URI) [[Rhode Island Rams men's basketball|men's basketball team]] also played some home basketball games at the Providence Civic Center beginning in 1973, although this practice stopped with the opening of the [[Ryan Center]] in 2002. In [[2010 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament|2010]], the arena hosted first and second-round games of the [[NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament]] for the first time since [[1996 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament|1996]].{{cite news |title='Impressed? Yes'|first=Paul|last=Grimaldi|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/projo/doc/397860730.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Mar+21%2C+2010&author=Grimaldi%2C+Paul&pub=The+Providence+Journal&edition=&startpage=&desc=%27Impressed%3F+Yes%27|newspaper=[[The Providence Journal]]|date=March 21, 2010|accessdate=June 10, 2014|page=A1}} ====Professional sports==== The [[Providence Reds]] (later known as the Rhode Island Reds) hockey team of the [[American Hockey League]] (AHL) played at the Providence Civic Center from 1972 to 1977. The [[New England Tea Men]] of the [[North American Soccer League (1968–84)|North American Soccer League]] (NASL) played their [[indoor soccer]] matches there from 1979–1980 before moving south to [[Jacksonville, Florida]] at the start of the [[1980–81 NASL Indoor season|1980–81 indoor season]].{{cite news |title=Tea Men Are Leaving N.E. for New Home in Florida|agency=[[Associated Press]]|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1915&dat=19801117&id=FwAhAAAAIBAJ&sjid=DHUFAAAAIBAJ&pg=5852,3483492|newspaper=[[The Day (New London)]]|date=November 17, 1980|accessdate=June 10, 2014|page=28}}{{cite web |title=April 10, 1982 – Jacksonville Tea Men vs. New York Cosmos|url=http://www.funwhileitlasted.net/tag/jacksonville-tea-men/|work=Fun While It Lasted|accessdate=June 10, 2014}}{{cite web |title=Attendance Project: NASL Indoor|url=http://www.kenn.com/the_blog/?page_id=5365|work=Kenn Blog|accessdate=June 10, 2014}} The [[Providence Bruins]] of the AHL began play at the arena in 1992. The [[New England Steamrollers]] of the [[Arena Football League]] also called the arena home for their single season of existence in 1988. A number of other professional sporting events, including [[Harlem Globetrotters]] basketball games and regular season and preseason games for the [[Boston Celtics]] of the [[National Basketball Association]] (NBA) have been held at the arena. {| class="wikitable" ! style="{{NBA color cell|Boston Celtics}}"|Date ! style="{{NBA color cell|Boston Celtics}}"|Opponent ! style="{{NBA color cell|Boston Celtics}}"|Result ! style="{{NBA color cell|Boston Celtics}}"|Home ! style="{{NBA color cell|Boston Celtics}}"|Game Type ! style="{{NBA color cell|Boston Celtics}}"|Attendance |- | style="{{NBA color cell2|Boston Celtics}}"|December 30, 1972 || [[Philadelphia 76ers]] || 107-117 || [[Boston Celtics]] || [[Regular season|RS]] || 9,065 |- | style="{{NBA color cell2|Boston Celtics}}"|October 9, 2013 || [[New York Knicks]] || 103-102 || [[Boston Celtics]] || [[Preseason|PS]] || 10,404 |- |} ===Circus=== During a live performance of the [[Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circus]] on May 4, 2014, eight female performers were sent to the hospital after a high wire snapped while they were attempting a routine where they [[Hair hang|hang by their hair]] high above the floor. The performers fell from between 25 and 40 feet to the ground, but none suffered life-threatening injuries.{{cite news |title=Performers Hurt in Platform Collapse at Providence Circus|first1=Doug|last1=Saffir|first2=Robert|last2=Burgess|url=http://www.boston.com/news/local/rhode-island/2014/05/04/report-aerial-performers-fall-during-circus-act-providence/jONRVASHacmTEy106u394M/story.html|newspaper=[[The Boston Globe]]|date=May 4, 2014|accessdate=June 10, 2014}} On May 1, 2016, Ringling Bros. ended 145 years of tradition when they staged their last-ever performance with live elephants at the Dunkin' Donuts Center.{{cite web|title=01 May RECAP: Ringling Bros. Last Elephant Show from Providence, RI|url=https://www.ringling.com/last-elephant-show/|website=Ringling Bros. & Barnum & Bailey|publisher=Ringling Bros. & Barnum & Bailey|accessdate=2 March 2017}} Eleven elephants headed to Florida for retirement after the show. A year after that, the final show for the Red Unit of Ringling Bros. was on May 7, 2017. ===Other events=== The arena has long been a regular stop on [[WWE]] tours. It was the site of [[WWE#World Wrestling Federation|WWF]] [[King of the Ring]] tournaments four times: from 1987 to 1991, before the event became a [[pay-per-view]], and once after in 1997. In 1994, it hosted the [[Royal Rumble (1994)|Royal Rumble]]. On April 25, 1999, the arena was home to the first ''[[Backlash: In Your House|WWF Backlash]]'' pay-per-view event, and the [[Backlash (2009)|2009 edition]] of the event (the last until 2016) was held there ten years to the day.{{cite web |title=WWE News: Backlash 2009 Location, South Dakota Rating, Press Release|url=http://www.411mania.com/wrestling/news/75384/WWE-News%3A-Backlash-2009-Location%2C-SD-Rating%2C-Press-Release.htm|work=411 Mania|date=May 12, 2008|accessdate=June 10, 2014}} In December 2005 the arena hosted ''[[Armageddon (2005)|WWE Armageddon]]''. The January 13, 2014 edition of ''[[WWE Raw]]'' was filmed at the arena. ''[[WWE Smackdown]]'' filmed two shows at the arena in 2015, on April 21 and August 25. The SmackDown portion of the [[2018 WWE Superstar Shake-Up]] was held at the Dunkin' Donuts Center, while the Raw portion was held at the [[XL Center]] in [[Hartford, Connecticut]]. On October 22, 2018, [[Roman Reigns]] revealed his [[leukemia]] diagnosis during a ''Raw'' show held at the arena. In November 2015, the [[Rhode Island Comic Con]] expanded into the arena from the adjacent [[Rhode Island Convention Center]], where it had been held since it began in 2012. It has been held in both buildings ever since. The arena was used by [[Hasbro]] to host its first-ever [[HasCon]] in September 2017. ==Gallery== File:DunkinDonutsCenter2.jpg|View of the center while empty, after renovations File:DunkMJ.jpg|The arena before [[Monster Jam]], prior to renovations File:DunkinDonutsCenter.jpg|Arena in hockey configuration, after renovations File:Providence College Syracuse.jpg|[[Syracuse Orange men's basketball|Syracuse]] vs. Providence College men's basketball game in February 2010 ==See also== * [[List of NCAA Division I basketball arenas]] * [[Rhode Island Convention Center]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== {{commons category}} *[http://www.dunkindonutscenter.com Official website] *[http://www.friars.com/facilities/prov-dunkin-donuts-center-dev.html FRIARS.COM – The Dunkin' Donuts Center] {{s-start-collapsible|header={{s-sta|et}}}} {{succession box | title = Host of the

{{EngvarB|date=October 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{Lead rewrite|date=December 2009}} ''The '''Famine Song''''' is a song sung by some [[Ulster loyalist]]s in [[Ulster]] and [[Scotland]] and is normally directed at Catholics and, in Scotland, [[Irish people]], [[Irish diaspora|those of Irish descent]] or those with perceived affiliations to [[Ireland]].{{cite web|title=Loyalist band's actions 'totally inappropriate'|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-18848591|publisher=[[BBC News]]|date=15 July 2012}} It is also sung by fans of Scottish [[association football|football]] club [[Rangers F.C.|Rangers]] due to rival [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]]'s Irish roots. Set to the tune of ''[[The John B. Sails]]'' popularised by [[Carl Sandburg]], the lyrics of the song make reference to the 1840s' [[Great Famine (Ireland)|Great Famine]] of Ireland. The song is often heard at loyalist marches in [[Northern Ireland]]. ''The Famine Song'' has received criticism due to the racist and sectarian nature of its lyrics and, in some cases, those singing it have received criminal convictions. ==Controversy== The [[Great Famine (Ireland)|Great Famine]] in [[Ireland]] during the 1840s led the country's population to fall from approximately 8 million to 5 million as a result of starvation and emigration.Edward Laxton, ''The Famine Ships: The Irish Exodus to America 1846–51'', Bloomsbury, 1997, {{ISBN|0-7475-3500-0}} Although the bulk of emigrants moved to North America, large numbers moved to Scotland and England, settling in London, Liverpool and Glasgow.Christine Kinealy, ''This Great Calamity'', Gill & Macmillan (1994), {{ISBN|0-7171-4011-3}}, 357. Since then, [[sectarianism in Glasgow]] in particular has received much media attention, with its two main football teams being focal points of identity: Celtic drawing large support from the descendants of [[Irish Catholics]], and Rangers from Protestants in [[Scotland]] and [[Ulster]] (chiefly [[Northern Ireland]] and [[County Donegal]]). [[Lex Gold]], the [[Scottish Premier League]] (SPL) chief executive at the time, said that football clubs could be deducted points if fans continue to sing such songs:
Clubs know they need to be alert and make sure their fans are doing all they can to avoid sectarian or other offensive abuse. The verse of the song that has featured hugely is racist, it's not sectarian as such, it's racist. The rules were structured to help to try to tackle this. You don't start with points deduction. We have a range of sanctions which can be applied.{{cite web |url=http://www.eveningtimes.co.uk/sport/display.var.2465535.0.gold_ill_dock_points_if_clubs_fail_in_fan_duty.php | title=Gold: I'll dock points if clubs fail in fan duty| work=www.eveningtimes.co.uk | publisher=Evening Times Online |date=November 2008 | accessdate=6 November 2008}}
[[John Reid, Baron Reid of Cardowan|John Reid]], Celtic's chairman, tried to highlight the non-Catholic specific aspects of the famine: "Few of those who sing this song will have stopped to think that famine is non-sectarian and the millions of people who died or were forced into mass emigration – some to Scotland – were from all faiths and traditions within Ireland.{{cite web | url=http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/football/spl/celtic/2008/09/29/rangers-famine-song-is-racist-says-john-reid-86908-20759736/ |title= Rangers' Famine Song is racist, says John Reid|work=Daily Record Online|publisher=www.dailyrecord.co.uk|date=September 2008|accessdate=6 November 2008}} The [[Republic of Ireland]]'s Consul-General approached the [[Scottish Government]] regarding the song. A Scottish Government spokesman said: "The Scottish Government is totally committed to combating sectarianism and bigotry, which is why we have expanded on the work of the previous administration and are doing more. We are working with the clubs themselves, as they are part of the solution to the problem.{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/glasgow_and_west/7617518.stm|title=Concerns raised over famine song |work=BBC News|publisher=news.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=6 November 2008 | date=15 September 2008}} Kenny Scott, Rangers' Head of Security and Operations, said in October 2008 that conversations with the [[Strathclyde Police]] made it clear to the club that there was the potential for supporters singing the song to be arrested.{{cite web|url=http://www.rangers.premiumtv.co.uk/page/Headlines/0,,5~1436866,00.html |title=Famine Song Statement |work=Rangers Official Club Site – News |publisher=www.rangers.premiumtv.co.uk |accessdate=6 November 2008 }}{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} In November 2008, a Rangers fan was found guilty of a breach of the peace (aggravated by religious and racial prejudice) for singing the song during a game in [[Kilmarnock]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.kilmarnockstandard.co.uk/ayrshire-news/news-east-ayrshire/kilmarnock-news/2008/11/26/rangers-fan-guilty-over-singing-famine-song-at-rugby-park-81430-22348515/ |title=Rangers fan guilty over singing Famine Song at Rugby Park |publisher=Kilmarnock Standard |date=26 November 2008 |accessdate=15 March 2012}} At his appeal in June 2009, three Scottish judges ruled that the song is racist because it targets people of Irish origin.{{Cite web|url=http://sport.stv.tv/football/103590-court-rules-famine-song-is-racist/|title=Court Rules Famine Song is Racist|work=stv|date=June 2009|accessdate=4 August 2009}}{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/glasgow_and_west/8109359.stm|title=Judges brand Famine Song 'racist'|work=BBC|accessdate=7 August 2009 | date=19 June 2009}} A Rangers fans' organisation, the [[Rangers Supporters' Trust]], denied that the song is racist: It instead described the song as a "wind-up" that is designed to mock not the famine itself, but Celtic fans' perceived affiliations with the [[Republic of Ireland]].{{cite web | url = http://www.rangerssupporterstrust.co.uk/rstsite/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=234&Itemid=43 | title = POSITION STATEMENT ON 'THE FAMINE SONG' |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090109081442/http://www.rangerssupporterstrust.co.uk/rstsite/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=234&Itemid=43 |date=3 October 2008 |archivedate=9 January 2009 |accessdate=23 October 2015}} In the context of their charitable projects in partnership with Rangers, [[UNICEF]] expressed their concern regarding the song and called on the club to ensure it was not sung at their matches.{{cite news|title=Unicef: Famine Song banned|first=Stuart|last=MacDonald|url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/unicef-famine-song-banned-r3ks9zc75kv|newspaper=The Sunday Times|date=10 January 2009|access-date=6 March 2011}} ==Legal issues== In the case of ''William Walls v. the [[Procurator Fiscal]], [[Kilmarnock]]'',{{Cite web|url=http://www.scotcourts.gov.uk/opinions/2009HCJAC59.html |title=WILLIAM WALLS v. PROCURATOR FISCAL, KILMARNOCK, 19 June 2009, Lord Carloway+Sheriff Principal Brian A Lockhart+Sheriff Principal R.A. Dunlop, Q.C |publisher=Scotcourts.gov.uk |date=19 June 2009 |accessdate=2 November 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090925023036/http://www.scotcourts.gov.uk/opinions/2009HCJAC59.html |archivedate=25 September 2009}} the [[High Court of Justiciary]] held on appeal, in an opinion delivered by [[Colin Sutherland, Lord Carloway|Lord Carloway]], that: :''"the song calls upon persons of Irish descent, who are living in Scotland, to go back to the land of their ancestors, namely Ireland [...] they are racist in calling upon people native to Scotland to leave the country because of their racial origins. This is a sentiment which, once more, many persons will find offensive."'' The appellant, who was convicted for [[breach of the peace]] racially aggravated and aggravated by religious prejudice having sung the Famine Song and made a number of other remarks during a football match, had his appeal denied and his conviction upheld. ==See also== *[[Irish diaspora]] *[[Irish-Scots]] *[[Old Firm]] *[[Sectarianism in Glasgow]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Famine Song}} [[Category:Football songs and chants]] [[Category:Immigration to Scotland]] [[Category:Great Famine (Ireland)]] [[Category:Irish diaspora]] [[Category:Racism in Scotland]] [[Category:Racism in sport]] [[Category:Rangers F.C. songs]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox Figure Skating Element |element name= Spin |scoring abbrev= Sp }} '''Spins''' are an element in [[figure skating]] where the skater rotates, centered on a single point on the ice, while holding one or more body positions. The skater rotates on the part of the blade just behind the [[toe pick]], with the weight on the ball of the foot. There are many types of spins, identified by the position of the arms, legs, and torso, the foot on which the spin is performed, and the entrance to the spin. A ''combination spin'' is a spin where the skater would connect a spin with another separate spin. Spins are a required element in most [[figure skating competitions]]. ==Types of spins== There are many types of spins, identified by the foot on which the spin is performed, the entrance to the spin, and the position of the arms, legs, and torso. Spins may be performed on either foot. Figure skaters are rarely able to spin in both directions; most favor one or the other. For skaters who rotate in a counterclockwise direction, a spin on the left foot is called a ''forward'' or ''front spin'', while a spin on the right foot is called a ''back spin''. Spins may be entered with a step or a jump. Spins entered with a jump are referred to as ''flying spins''. There are three basic positions, for which many variations exist. There are five levels of difficulty — Level B to Level 4. ===Upright spins=== An '''[[upright spin]]''' is a spin where the skater is in an upright position and their head is in line with their spine. There are many variations on it. *A '''basic two-foot spin''' is an upright spin in which the skater rotates with both feet on the ice using their arms to swing around and create momentum. *A '''basic one-foot spin''' is an upright spin in which the skater rotates with one foot on the ice. Spins can be skated on either foot. *A '''scratch spin''' is an upright spin with the free leg crossed in front of the skating leg. The arms and free leg begin in an open position, extended straight out and high. They are pulled in gradually, which accelerates the spin, and the leg is pushed down so that the feet are crossed at the ankles. This spin is performed on a very tight backward inside edge. *A '''back scratch''' is similar to the forward scratch spin, only performed on the opposite foot and on a tight backward outside edge. This is usually learned soon after the scratch spin is mastered, and is the basic air position for [[Figure skating jumps|jumping]]. *A '''crossfoot spin''' is a back upright spin in which the free leg is crossed behind the skating foot, or the front foot on a back upright is lowered and the spin becomes a two-footed spin. When spinning counter-clockwise, the left skate spins forward while the right skate travels backwards. *A '''[[layback spin]]''' is an upright spin, usually performed by women, in which the back is arched and head dropped back, the free leg in an [[Glossary of ballet terms#Attitude|attitude]] position, and the arms often stretched to the ceiling. A common variation of this spin is the '''catch foot layback''' or '''haircutter''', in which the skater grabs the free blade and pulls it toward her head while in the layback position. *An '''attitude spin''' looks a little bit like a very shallow layback, the skater turns her head and looks to the side, instead of arching and looking up, while the free leg is held in [[Glossary of ballet terms#Attitude|attitude]] position as for a layback spin. The leg position is the feature of this variation. It is often taught as an introductory position while learning a layback. *A '''[[Biellmann spin]]''' is a variation of the layback spin and performed by pulling the free leg from behind up and over the head. The blade of the skate may be held with either one or both hands. This requires extreme flexibility in the shoulders, back, hips, and legs. It was popularized by and named after 1981 World Champion [[Denise Biellmann]]. *'''"I" spins''' (or '''upright front-grab spins''') are a collection of spins when the skater pulls the free leg up in front of his or her face in a near-vertical angle (depending on the type of grab). {{Citation needed|date=May 2007}} *A '''shotgun spin''' is a variation of the upright front-grab spins in which the free leg is held in a horizontal position.{{Citation needed|date=May 2007}} This is also known as a spiral spin. *'''"Y" spins''' are spins in which the free leg is held with the hand and extended to the side in a near-split position. [[Michelle Kwan]] is known for doing this variation consecutively on both feet. The support can be from either or both arms, and the hold can either be on the skate or the ankle.{{Citation needed|date=May 2007}} ====Photo gallery of upright spins==== File:Karel Zelenka Spin - 2007 Europeans.jpg|

An "A" spin
([[Jeffrey Buttle]])
 ===Sit spins=== A '''[[sit spin]]''' is defined as a spin in which the buttocks are not higher than the level of the skating knee. There are many variations on it. * A basic '''sit spin''' is a spin in which the skater is in a [[shoot the duck]] position where the skating leg bent and the free leg extended forwards. *A '''broken leg sit spin''' is a sit spin in which the skater's free leg is turned inwards at the hip. *The '''corkscrew sit spin''' is a back sit spin in which the skater crosses the free leg behind the skating foot, rather than extending it to the front.{{Cite web|url=https://icoachskating.com/corkscrew-spin-spaghetti-spin-figure-skating-spins-bobbe-shire/|title=Corkscrew Spin, Spaghetti Spin - Figure Skating Spins (Bobbe Shire) {{!}} iCoachSkating|website=icoachskating.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-01-17}} *A '''flying sit spin''' is a sit spin entered from a jump; the skater attains the sit spin position in the air. * A '''pancake spin''' is a difficult variation on a sit spin[http://www.usfigureskating.org/content/Rule%20Clarifications%2011.08.05.pdf U.S. Figure Skating: Answers to Questions from Conference Call] in which the free leg is canted towards the body and upper body is bent over it, forming the illusion of the skater's body as a pancake. * A '''cannonball spin''' is a difficult variation similar to the pancake in which the free skate touches the thigh of the skating leg and arms are held down and touching the skating leg, giving the illusion of a cannonball. "Cannonball spin" is also commonly used to refer to a sit spin in which the skater holds the ankle of the extended free leg and lowers the chest flat to the thigh of the free leg.{{Citation needed|date=August 2007}} *A '''death drop''' is a flying spin performed by jumping up with a forward takeoff, kicking the same takeoff leg backwards, and landing in a back sit position. One of the major differences between a ''death drop'' and a regular ''flying sit spin'' is the position the skater attains in the air, which is almost horizontal to the ice in the death drop. [[Brian Boitano]] was known for his death drop. ====Photo gallery of sit spins==== Image:Sit spin.jpg|
Sit spin
([[Kimmie Meissner]])
Image:Jennifer Don 2.jpg|
Flying sit spin
([[Jennifer Don]])
Image:Alban Preaubert - piruet 2.JPG|
Sit spin with twist variation
([[Alban Préaubert]])
Image:Death drop.jpg|
Death drop jump take off
([[Ryan Jahnke]])
Image:Joubert 09Eurosp by Carmichael.jpg|
Death drop jump in the air
([[Brian Joubert]])
Image:Kevin Van Der Perren - piruet.JPG|
Pancake spin
([[Kevin Van Der Perren]])
 ===Camel spin=== A camel spin is defined as a spin in which the free leg is held backwards with the knee higher than the hip level. There are many variations on it. * A basic '''[[camel spin]]''' (also known as a parallel or arabesque spin) is performed by assuming an [[Glossary of ballet terms#A|arabesque]] position (or [[spiral (figure skating)|spiral]] position) with the free leg extended behind at hip level, parallel to the ice surface. * A '''flying camel spin''' is a back camel spin from a jump entry. * An '''illusion spin''' has a basic position similar to the camel, but instead of remaining "flat" throughout the duration of the spin the skater's body tilts up and down while the skater is spinning. The up-down cycle should coincide with the rotational speed so that the "low point" is always at the same point on the circle. This causes the spin to create an image that looks like a plate tilted at an angle. *A '''doughnut spin''' is a camel spin in which the skater pulls the blade of the skate of the free leg backward with one or both arms while arching the back to create a horizontal circular shape with the body. This is sometimes known as a horizontal [[Biellmann spin|Biellmann]], and some skaters use this to enter the [[Biellmann spin|Biellmann]] position.{{Citation needed|date=May 2007}} {{cite web|url=http://gofigureskating.com/skills/spins/DoughnutSpin.html}} *A '''butterfly spin''' is a flying spin with a near-horizontal body position and scissoring leg action in the air similar to that of the death drop, but it has a two-foot, twisting takeoff rather than an Axel-like takeoff. Butterflies can also be done as a solo move, without a spin, or in a series.{{Citation needed|date=May 2007}} ====Photo gallery of camel spins==== Image:Emily Hughes 2.jpg|
Camel spin
([[Emily Hughes]])
Image:Donut spin.jpg|
Donut spin
([[Shizuka Arakawa]])
Image:Ben Ferreira 2.jpg|
Butterfly jump
([[Ben Ferreira]])
Image:Camel yuna1.jpg|
Bent-leg layover spin
([[Yuna Kim]])
Image:VolosharMorozov SP EC2007.JPG|
Side by side camel spins
([[Tatiana Volosozhar]] / [[Stanislav Morozov]])
 ==Change of edge== *Forward change-edge spins, where the skater spins on the forward outside edge when in a forward spin rather than the normal backward inside edge. This is not a change of position, but a "difficult variation" which garners supplementary points in the [[ISU Judging System]]. This is most commonly seen as a camel on a forward outside edge. *Backward change-edge spins, where the skater goes on the forward inside edge when in a backward spin rather than the normal backward outside edge. This is not a change of position, but a "difficult variation" which garners supplementary points in the [[ISU Judging System]]. This is commonly seen in all of sit, camel, and upright positions. ==Combination spins== Spin positions performed in immediate succession without checking out of the spin are referred to as combination spins. In a combination spin, a skater may change position, change foot, change edge, or any combination of the above. Combination spins are delineated with the abbreviation '''CoSp''' in ISU Judging system protocols. ==Pair skating and ice dance== In [[pair skating]], skaters perform ''pair spins'' and ''side-by-side spins''. In side-by-side spins, the skaters perform the same solo spin next to each other on the ice. Pairs sometimes shout auditory cues to their partner in order to maintain and adjust their timing. In pair spins, the skaters hold onto each other and rotate together, but may be in different positions. In [[ice dancing]], skaters perform ''dance spins'', which are similar to pair spins. They do not perform side-by-side spins. ===Photo gallery of pair spins=== Image:Dominika Piatkowska & Dmitri Khromin Spin - 2006 Skate America.jpg|

 ==References== {{Reflist|30em|refs= {{cite web | url = http://static.isu.org/media/143595/1861-sandp_sov_levels-of-difficulty_goe_2014-15.pdf | format = PDF | title = Communication No. 1861: Single & Pair Skating Scale of Values, Levels of Difficulty and Guidelines for marking Grade of Execution | work = International Skating Union | date = 28 April 2014 }} {{cite news | url = http://web.icenetwork.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20120615&content_id=33342434&vkey=ice_news | title = Synchronicity: Teams work to maintain unison | first = Sarah S. | last = Brannen | work = Icenetwork | date = 15 June 2012 }} {{cite web | last = "Kay" K. Recognizing the Spins - Sit Spin | date = 2004-02-25 | url = http://www.sk8stuff.com/f_recog/recog_s_sit.htm | accessdate = 2007-05-10 }} }} ==See also== *[[Whirling]] == External links == {{commons category|Figure skating spins}} * [http://www.isu.org/en/single-and-pair-skating-and-ice-dance International Skating Union] * [http://skateguard1.blogspot.ca/2017/05/the-history-and-evolution-of-spinning.html The History And Evolution Of Spinning (Skate Guard blog)] {{Figure skating}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Figure Skating Spins}} [[Category:Figure skating elements|Spin Figure-skating]]

'''Finnish pesäpallo match-fixing scandal''' was a [[match fixing]] scandal in [[Finland]] that involved a large number of players, managers and other team officials of the [[pesäpallo]] (the Finnish form of [[baseball]]) league [[Superpesis]].
== The scam == On 11 and 13 August 1998 players and managers of eight teams fixed five different matches. All games were on the [[Fixed-odds betting|betting list]] of Finnish national betting agency [[Veikkaus]]. Matches were of two last rounds on the Superpesis regular season and they were meaningless for the teams. Four matches out of five ended on a high [[odds]] [[Tie (draw)|draw]] after two periods.<ref name=ts>{{cite web|url=http://www.ts.fi/urheilu/1074087892/Sopupeleista+tuomiot+34+ihmiselle |title= Sopupeleistä tuomiot 34 ihmiselle |publisher=Turun Sanomat |date=December 13, 2005 | language = Finnish |accessdate=May 4, 2013}}</ref>
The scam was unveiled a year later. Finnish police interrogated 460 persons involving the scandal. Most of them were never accused due to lack of evidence or for the reason that they were only lucky gamblers who had a hint on the results of meaningless games. Over 30 people were sentenced to [[Fine (penalty)|fines]] or [[Discharge (sentence)|discharged]]. They caused Veikkaus losses of at least 14 million [[Finnish markka|Finnish marks]] (2,3 million [[euro]]s).<ref name=ts/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hs.fi/tulosta/1135249027230 |title= Paras peli meille suomalaisille |publisher=Helsingin Sanomat |date=September 3, 2009 | language = Finnish |accessdate=May 4, 2013}}</ref>
== Aftermath == All teams involved were relegated two levels down in the league system and Veikkaus decided to ban all betting on pesäpallo matches for six years. The agency started taking bets again in 2005. Betting on a draw was not allowed until 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hs.fi/urheilu/artikkeli/Tasapeli%C3%A4kin+voi+veikata+taas+pitk%C3%A4vedon+pesiskohteissa/1135245715009 |title= Tasapeliäkin voi veikata taas pitkävedon pesiskohteissa |publisher=Helsingin Sanomat |date=May 5, 2009 | language = Finnish |accessdate=May 4, 2013}}</ref> The Finnish pesäpallo association lost a part of its state financing.
The common interest on pesäpallo, which is considered to be the [[National sport|national game]] of Finland, was decreasing for many years. However, in last few years the game has managed to increase its popularity among Finnish sports spectators.
== Fixed matches == '''11 August 1998''' *SMJ, [[Seinäjoki]] – KaMa, [[Kankaanpää]] 1-2 (5-2,5-6,0-3) *Lippo, [[Oulu]] – Kiri, [[Jyväskylä]] 2-1 (4-2,4-5,0-0,3-1) '''13 August 1998''' *Tiikerit, [[Helsinki]] – HP, [[Hamina]] 2-1 (8-3,2-3,6-0) *SiiPe, [[Siilinjärvi]] – Juvan Pallo, [[Juva]] 0-2 (1-4,4-6) *KaMa, [[Kankaanpää]] – Lippo, [[Oulu]] 2-1 (0-6,4-0,2-1)
== References == <references/>
{{DEFAULTSORT:Finnish pesapallo match-fixing scandal}} [[Category:Pesäpallo]] [[Category:Match fixing|Finnish pesapallo scandal]] [[Category:Crime in Finland]] [[Category:Scandals in Finland]]

Max: 22,090 | website = {{URL|www.kfcyumcenter.com/}} }} The '''KFC Yum! Center''' is a multi-purpose [[sports arena]] in Downtown [[Louisville, Kentucky]], United States. It is named after the [[KFC]] restaurant chain and [[Yum! Brands]], the parent company of KFC. Adjacent to the [[Ohio River]] waterfront, it is located on Main Street between 2nd and 3rd Streets and opened on October 10, 2010.{{cite news |title=Hotel Removed From Arena Plan|first=Marcus|last=Green|url=http://www.courier-journal.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20070522/NEWS01/705220407/1008|newspaper=[[The Courier-Journal]]|location=Louisville|date=May 22, 2007|accessdate=May 22, 2007|page=A1}}{{cite news |title=First Look Inside the Arena|first=Marcus|last=Green|url=http://www.courier-journal.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20070424/NEWS01/704240412/1008|newspaper=[[The Courier-Journal]]|location=Louisville|date=April 27, 2008|accessdate=April 27, 2008|page=A1}} The arena is part of a $450 million project that includes a 975-car parking structure and floodwall. The [[Louisville Cardinals men's basketball|Louisville Cardinals men's]] and [[Louisville Cardinals women's basketball|women's]] basketball teams from the [[University of Louisville]] are the primary tenants of the arena complex. The U of L women's volleyball team began using the arena as a part-time home in 2011,{{cite press release|title=Volleyball Opens BIG EAST Play at KFC Yum! Center|url=http://www.gocards.com/sports/w-volley/spec-rel/092111aab.html|publisher=[[Louisville Cardinals|University of Louisville Department of Athletics]]|date=September 21, 2011|accessdate=September 22, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140102191643/http://www.gocards.com/sports/w-volley/spec-rel/092111aab.html|archivedate=January 2, 2014|df=mdy-all}} and made the arena its main home in 2012.{{cite web|title=Women's Voileyball: 2012–2013 Schedule|url=http://www.gocards.com/sports/w-volley/archive/lou-w-volley-sched-2012.html|publisher=[[Louisville Cardinals|University of Louisville Department of Athletics]]|accessdate=March 21, 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150709113722/http://www.gocards.com/sports/w-volley/archive/lou-w-volley-sched-2012.html|archivedate=July 9, 2015|df=mdy-all}} With 22,090 seats for basketball, it is the second-largest college arena by seating capacity in the Commonwealth of Kentucky, behind [[Rupp Arena]] at the [[University of Kentucky]], and the third-largest in the United States, behind the [[Carrier Dome]] at [[Syracuse University]] and Rupp Arena.{{cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/chrissmith/2014/03/17/college-basketballs-most-valuable-teams-2014-louisville-cardinals-on-top-again|title=College Basketball's Most Valuable Teams 2014: Louisville Cardinals On Top Again|last=Smith|first=Chris|publisher=[[Forbes (magazine)|Forbes]]|date=March 17, 2014}} The arena's current attendance record is 22,815, set March 9, 2013 against Notre Dame. Since its opening, the KFC Yum! Center has been a frequent spot for major concerts, as it is one of the larger arenas between [[Cleveland]] and [[Chicago]]. ==History== {{Update section|date=September 2015}} Early arena planning focused on two potential arena sites: one owned by the [[Louisville Water Company]] bounded by Liberty Street, Muhammad Ali Blvd, 2nd and 3rd Streets, and one owned by [[Louisville Gas & Electric]] (LG&E) on the waterfront between 2nd and 3rd Streets on Main.{{cite news |title=Study Says Water Co. Arena Site Would Cost Less Than LG&E Site|url=http://louisville.bizjournals.com/louisville/stories/2006/02/20/daily27.html|newspaper=[[American City Business Journals|Business First of Louisville]]|date=February 24, 2006|accessdate=February 24, 2006}} In March 2006, [[University of Louisville]] [[Louisville Cardinals men's basketball|men's basketball]] coach [[Rick Pitino]] stated he would not coach in an arena built at the water company site.{{cite news |last=Platt |first=Rachel |title=Pitino: Cards won't play at Water Company site|url=http://www.whas11.com/topstories/stories/WHAS11_TOP_PitinoArenaComments.80ab1e10.html|publisher=[[WHAS-TV|WHAS]]|location=Louisville|date=March 3, 2006|accessdate=March 3, 2006|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928014404/http://www.whas11.com/topstories/stories/WHAS11_TOP_PitinoArenaComments.80ab1e10.html|archivedate=September 28, 2007 }} This came at a time when the House budget committee earmarked funding for the arena only if it was built at the water company site. Others, including [[Papa John's Pizza]] founder [[John Schnatter]], a major donor to the U of L athletic program, criticized the LG&E location due to its higher cost. On March 10, 2006, [[Governor of Kentucky|Kentucky Governor]] [[Ernie Fletcher]] announced at a Louisville Arena Unity Rally that the location of the new arena would be at the LG&E site along the riverfront to maximize profits.{{cite news |title=Fletcher: 'Arena Will Be Built At Riverfront Site; End Of Story'|url=http://www.wave3.com/Global/story.asp?S=4581995|work=[[WAVE (TV)|WAVE]]|location=Louisville|date=March 10, 2006|accessdate=March 10, 2006}}{{dead link|date=November 2015}} The unexpected visit was supported by Louisville Mayor [[Jerry Abramson]]. One month later on April 23, 2006, the Louisville Arena Authority released the design for the interior. The number of seats increased from the original 19,000 to 22,000; it would be divided up between 11,348 seats in the lower bowl, with the remainder on the upper tier. The seat width also increased from 19 to 20 inches. Also included in the release was a proposed sports bar that would be located on the main concourse; it would be open year-round and have views of the Ohio River. The number of suites would increase to 72 that would be located on two levels between the main and upper concourses; they would be twice as large as those in [[Freedom Hall]]. A public plaza and concourse along Main Street was also revealed. Prior to the release of the design, an arena report urged the facility to incorporate energy-saving elements into the construction.{{cite news |title=Arena Report Urges Energy-Saving Features|first=Marcus|last=Green|url=http://www.courier-journal.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20070308/NEWS01/703080462|newspaper=[[The Courier-Journal]]|location=Louisville|date=March 8, 2007|accessdate=March 8, 2007|page=B3}} Other recommendations included the avoidance of large, blank walls, the inclusion of public art, and the provision of year-round uses inside the building. On May 21, 2007, the Louisville Arena Authority voted unanimously to remove a hotel from the arena project. The 425-room hotel, which was envisioned as one way to pay off the project, was deleted because other revenues to cover the $252 million construction cost were projected to be higher than expected. The hotel would have also taken land away from a public plaza along Main Street. The Greater Louisville Hotel and Lodging Association also supported the measure, stating that downtown Louisville had enough projected rooms. The hotel was expected to contribute $1.3 million in annual lease payments, but other sources of revenue were hoped to cover the $573 million in total debt over 30 years on a $339 million bond issue for the arena. Originally, the Kentucky Finance Cabinet projected $211 million in new tax revenues in 2005. A more recent and comprehensive survey was completed recently and the projected revenue increased to $265 million. The other sources of revenue to cover the deletion of the hotel include, * $265 million from a tax-increment financing district * The city's pledge of $206 million minimum * $179 million from interior advertising * $84 million facility fee * $63 million in luxury suite revenues * $37 million in building naming rights The removal of the hotel would allow for a wider Main Street plaza and would allow for new features, such as a Washington Street entrance. It would also allow for more design flexibility and would lend itself to host after-hour concerts and other events on the plaza. On April 19, 2010, it was announced that Louisville-based fast food chain [[Yum! Brands]] would pay $13.5 million for the naming rights{{cite news |title=Yum! Brands Gets Arena Naming Rights|url=http://www.whas.com/cc-common/news/sections/newsarticle.html?feed=283307&article=7012698|work=[[WHAS (AM)|WHAS]]|location=Louisville|date=April 19, 2010|accessdate=April 19, 2010}} and would sell the products of three of its chains—[[KFC]], [[Pizza Hut]] and [[Taco Bell]]—in seven concession stands within the arena.{{cite news |title=Yum! to Pay $13.5 Million to Name Downtown Arena|first=Marcus|last=Green|url=http://www.courier-journal.com/article/20100419/SPORTS02/4190326/1028/rss0702|newspaper=[[The Courier-Journal]]|location=Louisville|date=April 19, 2010|accessdate=April 19, 2010}} ==Features== {{Expand section|date=September 2015}} The arena's features include an integrated scoring and video display system, which includes large LED video displays within the seating bowl, with the display and control system provided by [[Daktronics]] of [[Brookings, South Dakota]]. ==Financing== [[File:Louisville waterfront arena cropped.jpg|right|300px|thumb|The arena seen from the [[Ohio River]], with [[George Rogers Clark Memorial Bridge|Clark Memorial Bridge]] to the left.]] As a result of the subtracted hotel and the revised projected revenues, the arena, which would have lost $123,000 a year originally, might turn a small profit. The arena would generate $9.2 million a year in rent, merchandise, concessions and other revenues, along with funds from a $2 ticket tax on every [[Louisville Cardinals men's basketball|Louisville men's basketball]] game during the first 30 years of the arena's operation. The arena would spend just under $9 million a year, generating an annual profit of $196,000. Another reason for the revised operating expenses is the reimbursement fee that the Louisville Arena Authority must pay to the Kentucky State Fair Board for the arena's impact on [[Freedom Hall]]. The decrease in revenues, from $1.3 million to $738,000 during the first 10 years of operations of the new arena, is the result of a revision taking into account fewer events for the center. On May 28, 2007, it was announced that the [[Louisville Metro Council]] will propose an arena-financing deal that would save city taxpayers $3.4 million/year, or $100 million over three decades.{{cite news |title=Deal Offers Protections on Arena Financing|first1=Marcus|last1=Green|first2=Dan|last2=Klepal|url=http://www.courier-journal.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20070528/NEWS01/705280414/1008|newspaper=[[The Courier-Journal]]|location=Louisville|date=May 28, 2007|accessdate=May 28, 2007|page=A1}} The proposal, required the arena officials to exhaust other revenue sources, such as naming rights and luxury suite sales, before asking the metro government to pay more than its minimum pledge. The minimum pledge is $206 million towards the construction of the arena in annual installments between 2010 and 2039. Under the deal, the Louisville Arena Authority can ask the local government for up to $3.5 million more a year to cover the debt only if at least five other sources are drained. If the Louisville Arena Authority has to use additional city funds for two straight years, the Louisville Metro Council has the right to audit the arena's revenues. The financing agreement allowed $339 million in bonds through the state of Kentucky's Economic Development Finance Authority to be issued to construct the $252 million arena. The total debt on the bonds, $573 million over 30 years, will be paid through several sources. These include the city's $206 million commitment, $265 million from a tax-increment financing district, $179 million from advertising rights inside the arena, $63 million from luxury box sales, and at least $37 million in arena naming rights. The tax-increment financing district will allow part of the anticipated growth in state taxes to help pay for the arena. The arena's share of that revenue is capped at $265 million, although the project will be able to use the excess revenues to pay down the debt. It is expected to generate $574 million over 20 years. In September 2008, financing was completed for the new waterfront arena. ==Construction== [[Image:Picture 2146LouisvilleArena.jpg|thumb|right|250px|The arena construction site in March 2010]] On May 3, 2007, construction began on a new electrical substation for [[Downtown Louisville]].{{cite news |title=Electrical Work First Sign of Planned Arena|first=Sheldon S.|last=Shafer|url=http://www.courier-journal.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20070503/NEWS01/705030394/1008|newspaper=[[The Courier-Journal]]|location=Louisville|date=May 3, 2007|accessdate=May 3, 2007|page=B1}} The previous substation, located on the block of River Road, Main, 2nd and 3rd Streets, was relocated across the street at 3rd and River Road. The new substation, projected to cost $63 million, was completed in October 2008, at which time the land that housed the old substation was transferred to the Louisville Arena Authority for construction of the new arena. Work started on the new arena in November 2008. The complex was officially completed on October 10, 2010. In June 2010, Gov. Steve Beshear and Mayor Jerry Abramson announced a new $3 million streetscape improvement project directly underneath the Clark Memorial Bridge, a three-block area from Main Street to River Road, which will be transformed into a plaza. This includes a new decorative lighting system under the refurbished Clark Memorial Bridge, wide sidewalks, seats, new pedestrian and festival areas, and extensive plantings, making this an inviting promenade for the new KFC YUM! Center. The project will be completed in time for the October 2010 opening of the arena.{{cite web|title=Second Street Transformation to Occur Near Arena |url=http://www.louisvilleky.gov/economicdevelopment/News/2010/TransformationonSecondStreettoTakePlace.htm |publisher=City of Louisville |accessdate=June 30, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100609174515/http://www.louisvilleky.gov/economicdevelopment/News/2010/TransformationonSecondStreettoTakePlace.htm |archivedate=June 9, 2010 |df= }} In 2010, the glassed-in [[skywalk]] system, called Louie Link, was extended across 3rd Street from the new $16 million Skywalk Garage, an eight-level, 860-space parking facility on 3rd Street, to the new KFC Yum! Center. ==Controversy== The Task Force meetings were not without controversy. At first, task force member and [[University of Louisville]] athletics director [[Tom Jurich]], along with University of Louisville president [[James R. Ramsey|James Ramsey]] and Task Force member [[John Schnatter]] (founder of [[Papa John's Pizza]]), were ardently opposed to a downtown site and supported instead a campus arena, or a new arena built near Freedom Hall at the [[Kentucky Exposition Center]]. Jurich and Ramsey would later support the waterfront site. Schnatter, joined by fellow task force member and [[Humana]] co-founder [[David Jones (businessman)|David Jones]], strongly supported a new arena at the water company site, located four blocks down 2nd Street, or the Exposition Center, which was the cheapest option. They paid over $200,000 for a study that showed the water company site would be much less expensive than the riverfront site. However, the two dropped their lobbying effort after it did not seem to change the minds of the rest of the task force.{{cite news |title=Two Give in on Arena Site|first=Sheldon S.|last=Shafer|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/courier_journal/doc/241398601.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Jun+23%2C+2006&author=&pub=Courier+-+Journal&edition=&startpage=&desc=Two+give+in+on+arena+site|newspaper=[[The Courier-Journal]]|location=Louisville|date=June 23, 2006|accessdate=March 21, 2015|page=A1}} In the final site recommendation vote, Schnatter was the only one to vote against the waterfront site. ==See also== * [[Sports in Louisville, Kentucky]] * [[List of attractions and events in the Louisville metropolitan area]] * [[List of NCAA Division I basketball arenas]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=April 2007}} {{Infobox Figure Skating Element |image= |imagesize= |caption= |element name= Loop Jump |alt name= Rittberger Jump |scoring abbrev= Lo |element type= [[Figure skating jumps|Jump]] |edges= |take off edge= Back Outside |landing edge= Back Outside |inventor= [[Werner Rittberger]] |named for= |disciplines= }}
The '''loop jump''' is a [[figure skating jump]] that takes off from a back outside edge and lands on the same backwards outside edge. For a jump with counterclockwise rotation, this is the right back outside edge. It is named from its similarity to the loop [[compulsory figures|compulsory figure]]. The invention is widely credited to [[Werner Rittberger]], and the jump is also known as the "Rittberger" in [[Europe]]. However, evidence exists that it may have been first done as early as the 1880s.<ref>''Figure Skating: Championship Techniques'' by [[John Misha Petkevich]]. [[Sports Illustrated]], 1989.</ref>
== Loop technique == <!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:LoopEntry.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Entry to a triple loop jump, showing the cross-legged position and strong shoulder check (top) and release of the check (bottom). {{deletable image-caption|Sunday, 4 October 2009}}]] --> [[File:Marissa Castelli & Simon Shnapir 2LoTh 2009 Junior Worlds.jpg|thumb|right|The entrance to a throw double loop jump.]]
To do a loop jump, a skater typically does a [[3 turn]] or [[mohawk turn]] onto a left back inside edge, then reaches into the circle on the right back outside edge while drawing the left foot (still on the ice) to cross in front of the right. The knees are deeply bent, so that it sometimes appears that the skater is almost in a sitting position. On the approach edge, the rotation is strongly checked with the shoulders facing into the circle. At takeoff, the skater lifts the left leg while simultaneously pushing off with the right; the rotational momentum for the jump comes from releasing the check of the shoulders and pressure on the edge, rather than by swinging the arms or free leg. The skater maintains the cross-legged position, known as a ''back spin position'', in the air before landing after one or more rotations. Some skaters use a controversial two-footed takeoff technique where both feet are used to gain more spring, similar to one used for the [[Salchow jump]].
==Loop history== The loop can also be done as a double, triple, or quadruple, with two, three, or four rotations, respectively. [[Dick Button]] performed the first triple loop jump at the [[1952 Winter Olympics]]. The first female skater known to be able to perform a triple loop was [[Gaby Seyfert]] in 1968. [[Yuzuru Hanyu]] (JPN) became the first skater in history to successfully land a quadruple loop in competition at the 2016 [[Autumn Classic International]].
Since the loop takes off the edge that is used as the landing edge for most jumps, it is often seen as the second element of a jump combination. In this case, it is necessary for the skater to keep the free leg (the left leg for a counterclockwise rotator) and the same shoulder forward on the landing of the preceding jump, instead of bringing it backward in the normal check-out or for a [[toe loop jump]]. The timing for loop-based combinations is thus much quicker than toe-loop-based combinations.
[[Éric Millot]] of [[France]] was the first skater to perform a triple loop/triple loop combination, in 1996. In the years since, doing triple loops in combination has become considered somewhat hazardous, since a number of skaters including [[1998 Winter Olympics|1998 Olympic]] champion [[Tara Lipinski]] have suffered serious [[hip (anatomy)|hip]] injuries from practicing them.
== Loop variants ==
A related jump in figure skating is the [[Euler jump]] (or ''half loop''). In spite of its name, it is a full rotation jump. It differs from a regular loop jump in that it is landed on the opposite foot, on a backward inside edge. Eulers are only done as single jumps and are primarily used as connecting elements in a jump sequence, before a [[salchow jump]] or [[flip jump]] which take off from a back inside edge. The Euler is normally taught to figure skaters after they are able to land their regular loop jump. This jump is also known as the ''Thoren'' (after [[Per Thorén]]), or very commonly, the ''Half Loop''.
The true half-rotation jump with a loop entrance, landed forward (on the left toe pick and right forward inside edge, for a counterclockwise jump), is called a ''falling leaf''. This jump can be performed with a split position at the peak of the jump, which is called a ''split falling leaf'' (see [[split jump]]).
The loop jump should not be confused with the [[toe loop jump]], which has significantly different mechanics and technique.

(2014)[http://lusakavoice.com/2014/04/01/zambian-coach-chris-tembo-has-been-fired-by-mbabane-swallows-with-immediate-effect/ Zambian Coach Chris Tembo has been fired by Mbabane Swallows with immediate effect] == Youth academy == Since 2011 the club holds with the Ishibobo Soccer Academy (ISA), an talent scouting sports academy in [[Manzini, Swaziland|Manzini]]. ISA serves as the under-20 football team of the club.[https://twitter.com/Ishibobo Ishibobo Soccer Academy under the brand name Manzini Sea Birds u-20] Ishibobo played his home matches on the Zakhele Sports Ground.[https://twitter.com/Ishibobo/status/283162077357539328 Zakhele Sports Ground Ishibobo Academy] == References == {{reflist}} == External links == *[https://int.soccerway.com/teams/swaziland/manzini-sea-birds-fc/22534/ Soccerway] {{Swazi Premier League}} [[Category:Football clubs in Eswatini]] {{Swaziland-footyclub-stub}}

==30 October 2007 (Tuesday)==
*[[Baseball]]: **[[2007 Japan Series]] *** Game 3: [[Chunichi Dragons]] 9, [[Hokkaido Nippon Ham Fighters]] 1. '''''Dragons lead series 2–1.''''' **[[Major League Baseball]]: *** The [[New York Yankees]] sign [[Joe Girardi]] to a three-year contract as the team's new manager. [http://sports.espn.go.com/mlb/news/story?id=3086315 (ESPN.com)] *** [[Grady Little]] resigns as [[Los Angeles Dodgers]] manager amid rumors that former Yankees manager [[Joe Torre]] will soon be signed. [http://sports.espn.go.com/mlb/news/story?id=3087421 (ESPN.com)] *[[Basketball]]: ** [[2007–08 NBA season]] – Season Openers *** [[2007–08 San Antonio Spurs season|San Antonio Spurs]] 106, [[2007–08 Portland Trail Blazers season|Portland Trail Blazers]] 97 *** [[2007–08 Utah Jazz season|Utah Jazz]] 117, [[2007–08 Golden State Warriors season|Golden State Warriors]] 96 *** [[2007–08 Houston Rockets season|Houston Rockets]] 95, [[2007–08 Los Angeles Lakers season|Los Angeles Lakers]] 93 *[[Football (soccer)]]: **[[FIFA]] announces that [[Brazilian Football Confederation|Brazil]] will host the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]] and [[German Football Association|Germany]] will host the [[2011 FIFA Women's World Cup]].
<div id="29_October_2007"> </div id>
==29 October 2007 (Monday)==
*[[American football]] ** [[2007 NFL season|National Football League]] Week 8: *** [[2007 Green Bay Packers season|Green Bay Packers]] 19, [[2007 Denver Broncos season|Denver Broncos]] 13 (OT) **** [[Brett Favre]] connects with [[Greg Jennings]] for an 82-yard touchdown pass on the first play from scrimmage in overtime. *[[Rugby union]]: **[[Jake White]], who coached [[South Africa national rugby union team|South Africa]] to the [[2007 Rugby World Cup]] title, resigns as Springboks head coach, effective at the end of 2007. [http://www.sarugby.net/component/supersportcontent/5749?view=news (South African Rugby Union)] *[[Cricket]]: **[[South African cricket team in Pakistan in 2007–08]] ***{{cr|RSA}} 233/9 (50 ov.) beat {{cr|PAK}} 219 (46.3 ov.) by 14 runs <div id="28_October_2007"> </div id>
==28 October 2007 (Sunday)==
*[[American football]] ** [[2007 NFL season|National Football League]] Week 8: *** [[2007 Philadelphia Eagles season|Philadelphia Eagles]] 23, [[2007 Minnesota Vikings season|Minnesota Vikings]] 16 *** [[2007 Cleveland Browns season|Cleveland Browns]] 27, [[2007 St. Louis Rams season|St. Louis Rams]] 20 *** [[2007 New York Giants season|New York Giants]] 13, [[2007 Miami Dolphins season|Miami Dolphins]] 10 (at [[Wembley Stadium]] in London) *** [[2007 Pittsburgh Steelers season|Pittsburgh Steelers]] 24, [[2007 Cincinnati Bengals season|Cincinnati Bengals]] 13 *** [[2007 Tennessee Titans season|Tennessee Titans]] 13, [[2007 Oakland Raiders season|Oakland Raiders]] 9 *** [[2007 Indianapolis Colts season|Indianapolis Colts]] 31, [[2007 Carolina Panthers season|Carolina Panthers]] 7 ****The Colts become the first team since the 1929–31 [[Green Bay Packers]] to start three straight seasons 7–0. [[Quarterback]] [[Peyton Manning]] throws two touchdowns to break [[Johnny Unitas]]' franchise record for career touchdown passes. *** [[2007 Detroit Lions season|Detroit Lions]] 16, [[2007 Chicago Bears season|Chicago Bears]] 7 *** [[2007 Jacksonville Jaguars season|Jacksonville Jaguars]] 24, [[2007 Tampa Bay Buccaneers season|Tampa Bay Buccaneers]] 23 *** [[2007 San Diego Chargers season|San Diego Chargers]] 35, [[2007 Houston Texans season|Houston Texans]] 10 *** [[2007 Buffalo Bills season|Buffalo Bills]] 13, [[2007 New York Jets season|New York Jets]] 3 *** [[2007 New Orleans Saints season|New Orleans Saints]] 31, [[2007 San Francisco 49ers season|San Francisco 49ers]] 10 *** [[2007 New England Patriots season|New England Patriots]] 52, [[2007 Washington Redskins season|Washington Redskins]] 7 ****The Patriots go to 8–0, setting up a matchup between two unbeaten teams when they travel to [[RCA Dome|Indianapolis]] next week. **In the same week, [[Peyton Manning]] and [[Tom Brady]] become the first quarterbacks to have beaten 31 of the 32 current NFL teams. Obviously, since both are with their original team, neither have beaten their own team. *[[Auto racing]]: **[[2007 NASCAR Nextel Cup Series|NASCAR]]: [[2007 Pep Boys Auto 500|Pep Boys Auto 500]] at [[Atlanta Motor Speedway|Hampton, Georgia]]: *:(1) [[Jimmie Johnson]] (2) [[Carl Edwards]] (3) [[Reed Sorenson]] * [[Baseball]]: ** [[2007 World Series]]: *** Game 4: [[Boston Red Sox]] 4, [[Colorado Rockies]] 3: ****The Red Sox win their second World Series in four years. Series [[World Series MVP Award|Most Valuable Player]] [[Mike Lowell]] scores from second on a [[Jason Varitek]] single in the fifth, then hits a solo home run in the seventh to give the Sox a 3–0 lead. Homers by Colorado's [[Brad Hawpe]] and [[Garrett Atkins]], sandwiching a solo shot by Boston's [[Bobby Kielty]], close the gap to 4–3. But Red Sox [[closer (baseball)|closer]] [[Jonathan Papelbon]] pitches 1⅔ innings for his third save of the series. '''''Red Sox win series 4–0'''''. ** [[2007 Japan Series]]: *** Game 2: [[Chunichi Dragons]] 8, [[Hokkaido Nippon Ham Fighters]] 1. '''''Series even 1–1.''''' ** Other news: *** [[Scott Boras]], the [[sports agent|agent]] for [[Alex Rodriguez]], announces that A-Rod will exercise his option to void the last four years of his contract with the [[New York Yankees]] and will become a [[free agent]].
<div id="27_October_2007"> </div id>

team|Ohio State]] 37, (24) [[2007 Penn State Nittany Lions football team|Penn State]] 17 *** (5) [[2007 Oregon Ducks football team|Oregon]] 24, (9) [[2007 USC Trojans football team|USC]] 17 *** (6) defeat a ranked team for the first time in 11 attempts as a Division I-A/FBS team. *** (12) [[2007 Kansas Jayhawks football team|Kansas]] 19, [[2007 Texas A&M Aggies football team|Texas A&M]] 11 **** The Jayhawks go to 8–0 for the first time since 1909. *** (13) [[2007 Missouri Tigers football team|Missouri]] 42, [[Iowa State Cyclones football#2007 Schedule|Iowa State]] 28 *** [[2007 Mississippi team|Minnesota]] 10 ([[Little Brown Jug (football)|Little Brown Jug]]) *** [[NC State Wolfpack#Football|NC State]] 29, (21) [[2007 Virginia Cavaliers football team|Virginia]] 24 *** (23) [[2007 Auburn Tigers football team|Auburn]] 17, [[Ole Miss Rebels#Football|Mississippi]] 3 * [[Baseball]]: ** [[2007 World Series]] *** Game 3: [[Boston Red Sox]] 10, [[Colorado Rockies]] 5. The Bosox slay the "Dragon Slayer" [[Josh Fogg]] with six runs in the third inning, let the Rockies back in the game with a five-run sixth, but pull away. The Sox are led on offense by [[Jacoby Ellsbury]], the first rookie since [[1936 World Series|1936]] with four hits in a Series game, and [[Dustin Pedroia]], with three hits of his own. '''''Red Sox lead series 3–0.''''' ** [[2007 Japan Series]] *** Game 1: [[Hokkaido Nippon Ham Fighters]] 3, [[Chunichi Dragons]] 1. '''''Fighters lead series 1–0.'''''<!--Don't know what convention Japan uses for scores... if anyone knows better, please change accordingly. Fighters were home team.--> * [[Football (soccer)]]: ** [[MLS Cup 2007]] – Conference Semifinals, first leg *** [[New England Revolution]] 0–0 [[New York Red Bulls]] *** [[Chivas USA]] 0–1 [[Kansas City Wizards]] *** [[Houston Dynamo]] 0–1 [[FC Dallas]] *[[Horse racing]]: [[2007 Breeders' Cup]] at [[Monmouth Park]] **[[Curlin]] wins the [[Breeders' Cup Classic]] in a powerful stretch drive, defeating his major rivals for [[Eclipse Award for Horse of the Year|U.S. Horse of the Year]] honors in [[Street Sense (horse)|Street Sense]] and [[Lawyer Ron]]. For the second straight year, a Breeders' Cup race is marred by tragedy, as European star [[George Washington (horse)|George Washington]] shatters an ankle in the Classic and is [[animal euthanasia|put down]] on the track. Other winners: **[[Breeders' Cup Juvenile Fillies|Juvenile Fillies]] — [[Indian Blessing]] **[[Breeders' Cup Juvenile|Juvenile]] — [[War Pass]] **[[Breeders' Cup Filly & Mare Turf|Filly & Mare Turf]] — [[Lahudood]] **[[Breeders' Cup Sprint|Sprint]] — [[Midnight Lute]] **[[Breeders' Cup Turf Mile|Turf Mile]] — [[Kip Deville]] **[[Breeders' Cup Distaff|Distaff]] — [[Ginger Punch]] **[[Breeders' Cup Turf|Turf]] — [[English Channel (horse)|English Channel]] * [[Rugby union]]: ** [[2007 Currie Cup]] Final *** [[Free State Cheetahs]] 20–18 [[Golden Lions]] at [[Free State Stadium|Bloemfontein]]

*[[Horse racing]]: [[2007 Breeders' Cup]] at [[Monmouth Park]] **[[Breeders' Cup Filly & Mare Sprint|Filly & Mare Sprint]] — [[Maryfield (horse)|Maryfield]] **[[Breeders' Cup Juvenile Turf|Juvenile Turf]] — [[Nownownow]] **[[Breeders' Cup Dirt Mile|Dirt Mile]] — [[Corinthian (horse)|Corinthian]]

==25 October 2007 (Thursday)== * [[American football]]: [[2007 NCAA Division I FBS football season|NCAA Division I FBS]] [[2007 NCAA Division I FBS football rankings|AP Top 25]]: ** (2) [[Boston College Eagles football#2007|Boston College]] 14, (8) [[2007 Virginia Tech Hokies football team|Virginia Tech]] 10 ***Amidst rainy conditions [[Lane Stadium|in Blacksburg]], the Eagles score two touchdowns in the last three minutes to overcome one of their major hurdles to an undefeated season. * [[Baseball]]: [[2007 World Series]] ** Game 2: [[Boston Red Sox]] 2–1 [[Colorado Rockies]], '''''Red Sox lead series 2–0.''''' *** [[Mike Lowell]] proves to be the difference-maker for the Red Sox, scoring on a [[Jason Varitek]] sacrifice fly in the 4th inning and then driving [[David Ortiz]] in with a double in the 5th. [[Matt Holliday]] provides four of the Rockies' five hits, but is picked off at first in the 8th inning by [[Jonathan Papelbon]]. Papelbon and [[Hideki Okajima]], who first relieved [[Curt Schilling]], combined for 3{{fraction|2|3}} innings of shutout relief, only giving up one hit to Holliday. * [[Football (soccer)]]: ** [[MLS Cup 2007]] – Conference Semifinals, first leg *** [[D.C. United]] 0–1 [[Chicago Fire S.C.|Chicago Fire]]
<div id="24_October_2007"> </div id>
==24 October 2007 (Wednesday)==
* [[Baseball]]: [[2007 World Series]] ** Game 1: [[Boston Red Sox]] 13–1 [[Colorado Rockies]], '''''Red Sox lead series, 1–0.''''' ***[[Dustin Pedroia]] leads off with a home run and the Sox never look back, handing the Rockies their first loss in ten games. [[Josh Beckett]] strikes out nine while giving up only one run in seven innings on the mound, while his counterpart [[Jeff Francis]] only lasted four innings, allowing six runs off ten hits.
<div id="23_October_2007"> </div id>
==23 October 2007 (Tuesday)==

==22 October 2007 (Monday)==
* [[American football]] ** [[2007 NFL season|National Football League]] Week 7: *** [[2007 Indianapolis Colts season|Indianapolis Colts]] 29, [[2007 Jacksonville Jaguars season|Jacksonville Jaguars]] 7 **** The Colts become the third team in NFL history to start three consecutive seasons at 6–0. Both [[David Garrard]] (sprained ankle) and [[Maurice Jones-Drew]] (sprained knee) were knocked out of the game for the Jags. * [[Major League Baseball]]: ** [[Tony La Russa]] agrees to a two-year deal to stay on as manager of the [[St. Louis Cardinals]]. [http://sports.espn.go.com/mlb/news/story?id=3073963 (AP via ESPN.com)] * [[Football (soccer)]]: ** Despite only one loss out of 55 matches, [[Greg Ryan (soccer)|Greg Ryan]] is sacked as coach of the [[United States women's national soccer team|USA women's national team]]. [http://soccernet.espn.go.com/news/story?id=474885&cc=5901 (AP via ESPNsoccernet)]
